speaker: H.E. John Agyekum Kufuor

speaker: H.E. John Agyekum Kufuor

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: What we achieved for ourselves last year in confronting inflation was therefore notable.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Many Honourable Members of the House who participate in International conferences both within and outside can confirm the positive view the international community holds of Ghana‚Äôs economic progress.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: This Administration intends to stay the course because there are no short cuts.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Ghana managed to maintain a respectable growth rate in 2010 and is poised to attain a higher level this year.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The World Bank predicts that Ghana would post the highest GDP in the world for the year 2011.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: I presented to Parliament last December Government‚Äôs Co-ordinated Programme of Economic and Social Development Policies for 2010-2016.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The main thrust of this programme is to transform the economy for accelerated growth and job creation.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: We aim to achieve this through accelerated human resource development, agricultural mechanization and value-added processing of our national resource endowments on the back of the new oil and gas resources.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: One of the highlights of the document is the establishment of Special Development Zones which is an initiative to reduce spatial and income inequality.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The Savannah Accelerated Development Authority (SADA) which is one of the NDC 2008 manifesto pledges has already commenced work.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: A donor‚Äôs conference is in the offing to commit funds for SADA‚Äôs operations.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The additional special zones we propose all of which will be under the Office of the President, will include; a. Western Corridor Development Authority which will subsume the Central Region Development Commission (CEDECOM); b. Eastern Corridor Development Authority which will have a mandate covering the Volta Region and Afram Plains; c. The Forest Belt Development Authority comprising the forest zones in the Eastern, Ashanti and Brong Ahafo Regions.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Our development partners have continued to offer development assistance and in some instances indicated their readiness to increase levels of assistance.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: We are grateful to them for recognizing the capacity, readiness and democratic integrity of this Administration to be reliable partners.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: This Government has achieved appreciable success in its effort to diversify the range of development assistance.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: We received pledges of substantial support especially towards infrastructural development during my visits to Japan and China in September last year.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: A special team has been working to ensure urgent follow up actions because as the old saying goes ‚Äì we must strike while the iron is hot.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The quantum of funding for infrastructure development that should be available to the economy following our visits to the Far East appears to have caused a stir among those who think the economy of Ghana is too small to absorb such substantial investments as if we are destined to remain a small economy.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Past failures seem to have created a mentality that has restricted national ambition.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: On our visit to the Far East last September we carried with us our blueprint for the rehabilitation and expansion of rail network in Ghana.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: We also had our blueprint for roads covering the Eastern Corridor spanning Ho all the way to Nkwanta, Kadjebi, Worawora, Yendi and beyond.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: We had the blueprint for the Western corridor stretching from Elubo through Enchi, Juaboso and all the way to Wa in the Upper West Region and beyond.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: These and other extensive road projects envisaged in the oil enclave namely Takoradi, Mpataba, Bonyere and elsewhere and economic roads in Tarkwa and Bogoso etc. are a statement of intent on where this Administration wants Ghana to be within the foreseeable future.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Agreements covering these projects will be laid before the House shortly and I count on the ready support of Honourable Members so that we can get going because as the old adage goes: Time and Tide wait for no man.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: We are now at least in theory ‚Äì a middle-income economy.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: When we compare the levels of development in other middle-income countries it would seem we have a lot of catching-up to do.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The substantial investments we secure will take us closer to the levels achieved by other middle-income countries in road and rail construction, in the oil and gas industry, education, health, provision of water, electricity and even waste management.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The provisional results of the 2010 census put Ghana‚Äôs population at a little over 24 million compared to the 2000 population figure of around 18 million.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: We have a lot of planning to do to raise living standards commensurate with our middle-income status.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The year 2010 certainly ended on a high, with the pumping of our oil in commercial quantities.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: As we join the ranks of oil-producing countries, I assure Ghanaians that this Government will account for every pesewa of the oil revenue.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The majority of Ghanaians accept that the policies and priorities of this government are in the right direction.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: I am also aware of the expectations for Government to act to lessen the economic burden especially following the increases in prices of some petroleum products.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: A social democratic Government such as ours gains nothing politically by increasing petroleum prices.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The debt must be settled for the sake of a healthy, sustainable economy and for the sake of ensuring that we can adequately cater for our development needs.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: This Administration has been bold and courageous in taking steps toward the implementation of the single spine salary regime.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The new salary structure goes a long way in bringing equity and improvement in salaries especially in the public sector.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Negotiations on a new minimum wage have been completed and the result is likely to influence collective bargaining negotiations.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: My appeal is for moderation in wage demands because large wage bills means less money for investment in needed infrastructure and provision of social amenities.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The Constitution Review Commission has since its inauguration last year employed a consultations strategy which is geared towards ensuring that Ghanaians within and outside the country get the opportunity to make inputs into the review process.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: It has targeted the 1st ‚Äì 5th March for the National Constitutional Conference that will finalize the amendment proposal to the Constitution.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: It is the intention of Government to ensure that relevant completed and ongoing policy reforms will be duly merged with the constitution review exercise to ensure a product that is holistic and reflective of our common heritage as Ghanaians.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Government will continue to support the Electoral Commission and ensure that we come out of the 2012 election with additional high flying democratic credentials.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: We indicated our general acceptance of the objectives of the 2004 'Women‚Äôs Manifesto for Ghana' which are based on the achievement of gender equality and equity in national development in our own Manifesto of 2008.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: This year, the Ministry of Women and Children‚Äôs Affairs will work with the sponsors of the Women‚Äôs Manifesto and other stakeholders to incorporate its key demands in a revised 'Affirmative Action for Women' which we hope to finalise by the end of the year.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: I have already made reference to the commissioning of oil from the Jubilee field.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: It is important to conclude the passage of the Petroleum Commission Bill which is before Parliament in order to give legal backing to issues of local content and participation in the petroleum sector.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: This Government remains committed to providing adequate and reliable supply of energy to households and industry.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The supply of natural gas from Nigeria through the West Africa Gas pipeline project commenced in March last year.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: This fuels two 100 megawatts gas turbines of the VRA as well as the Ho Asogli Thermal Plant.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Last year, the Aboadze to Volta transmission line was synchronized to the National Grid.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The construction of a 132 megawatts thermal power station in Takoradi also began last year and is scheduled for completion at the end of this year.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: We will be seeking Parliamentary approval for financing arrangements for the Takoradi International Company for the expansion of their capacity from 220 to 330 megawatts.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: High capacity new power transformers have been installed in Kumasi, Ho, Anekpe, Techiman and Takoradi to increase transmission capacity and ensure reliable supply at these stations.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The ECG is also undertaking construction of primary substations in Accra, Tema and Kumasi.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Over the past two years 705 towns have been connected to the national electricity grid.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: In 2011, more communities especially in the Western, Volta, Central, Northern, Upper East and Upper West Regions will be connected to the national electricity grid to close the regional distribution gap.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Modernization of agriculture, enhanced food security and creating job opportunities along the entire agricultural value chain are priorities of this Administration.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: There have been notable increases of maize, rice, sorghum, plantain and yam production.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The goal of this Administration to make locally produced food more abundant and affordable is on course.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The implementation plan for the National Irrigation Policy will be completed and launched during 2011.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The first phase of the Accra Plains Irrigation Project, covering an area of about 5000 hectares will be implemented to promote double and where possible, triple cropping of vegetables and cereals.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The Youth in Agriculture Programme has chalked some degree of success and its scope will be expanded this year.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The National Buffer Stock Company will this year improve its storage capacity of 34,000 metric tonnes to at least 60,000 metric tonnes.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The Company will also acquire a modern rice mill to enhance the processing of local paddy rice.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: We have not seen any case of guinea worm in Ghana since May 2010, when the last case was reported.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Regional Hospitals and staff housing at Wa, Kumasi, Sekondi-Takoradi and Tema will commence.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Other projects include the ongoing refurbishment of the Tamale Teaching Hospital and the expansion of Radiotherapy and Nuclear Medicine centres at the Korle-Bu and Komfo Anokye Teaching Hospitals.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Following the passage of the Mental Health Act, Government will adopt a community mental health care strategy to facilitate the implementation of the Act.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The required Legislative Instrument to operationalize other aspects of the Act will also be laid before Parliament.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: This year, we will further intensify our commitment to free exercise books, free school uniforms and turn more schools under trees into brick and mortar classroom blocks.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: We will also expand the Capitation Grant as well as the School Feeding Programme support.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The School Feeding Programme has been restructured in such a way that the development partners which earlier pulled out on account of poor financial and procurement audit reports are considering resuming their financial support for the programme.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Government will continue to provide incentives and motivation packages for teachers, especially those in deprived areas.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: We have noted the rate at which the computerized placement mechanism is blocking access to second cycle education by pupils from basic schools in the catchment areas.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: It has therefore been decided that from the 2011-12 academic year, the policy of selecting 30% of first year students from within 10-mile radius of where schools are situated will be restored.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The Ministry of Environment Science and Technology has already begun distributing computer notebooks to brilliant but needy science students.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: This Administration has also put in place a Tertiary Institutions Internal Access Programme (TIIAP) of institutions to benefit from a discounted laptop scheme.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The first batch of beneficiaries of the Mathematics, Science and Technology Scholarship Scheme as promised in our manifesto will be awarded scholarships before the end of March.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The scheme covers needy but brilliant science-biased students in second cycle and tertiary level institutions.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Government will continue to support the expansion of especially tertiary education including those in the private sector but will not allow a mushrooming of institutions without the appropriate accreditation.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: I have already cut the sod for work to begin on the promised two additional public universities in the Volta and Brong Ahafo Regions.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The sod-cutting for the commencement of works on the construction of the University of Health and Allied Sciences in the Volta Region, as well as the University of Energy and Natural Resources in the Brong Ahafo Region, is ample testimony to our commitment to breathe life into our manifesto pledges.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: I can confidently say that our roads sector expansion project is very much on course.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Ongoing or completed projects include Tetteh Quarshie-Madina, Asankragwa-Enchi, Achimota-Ofankor, Kumasi-Techiman (Phase 2).

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The Eastern Corridor road which links Accra through the Volta Region to the Northern Region will begin in earnest once this August House approves the financing arrangements.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Some progress is being made in the existing water supply situation.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Through rationing, many parts of Accra now have access to water.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The rehabilitation of water treatment plant and pipelines at Kpong is expected to start this year as well as the ongoing ATMA Rural Water Supply Project will go a long way in further improving water supply.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The Kwanyako-Kasoa Water Interconnection Project has brought relief to the people of Kasoa, Awutu, Senya Beraku, Gomoa Fetteh and its environs.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The expansion of Kumasi Barekese Water Treatment Plant has also been completed.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The water treatment plants at Konongo, Kumawu and Kwahu and other projects covering Damongo, Essakyer, Bolgatanga, Navrongo, Bongo as well as several other District capitals and towns throughout the country are concrete evidence of our determination to meet the Millennium Development Goals of water for all by 2015.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Our massive infrastructure expansion plans in the areas of housing, roads and railways, will open up lots of job opportunities for many categories of our labour force.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The National Youth Employment Programme (NYEP) continues to expand its operations and is giving employment to lots of our youth.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Our Youth in Agriculture Programme is also going to create more jobs especially after the Accra Plains irrigation project takes off.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Our security agencies have already started recruitment exercises which will see a number of our youth in uniform once they complete their training programmes.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: It is anticipated that once our financial institutions respond appropriately and reduce the cost of credit, the ability to access loans will stimulate industry growth which will in turn create opportunities for job creation.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: My Christmas card for last year featured a picture of the gallant Black Stars who did the nation proud in the 2010 World Cup in South Africa.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: I meant it as a signal that our country‚Äôs heroes will always be remembered and that Ghana is worth dying for.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The Youth and Sports Ministry is being tasked to collaborate with the GFA and private stakeholders to rebuild colts football as a base for the growth of Ghana‚Äôs football.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: We are going to make an effort to reorient the psyche of our youth towards what we consider to be Ghanaian values ‚Äì especially on the issue of moral consciousness.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The Ministry of Education will be working in conjunction with the Ministry of Chieftaincy and Culture as well as the relevant state and private entities to reinforce Arts and Culture Festivals in second cycle institutions.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Choral Festivals will be organized from the district to the national level.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The idea is to have a National Festival of Arts, Culture and Choral Music championed by the youth to reignite their sense of belonging.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: One governance issue that will forever remain close to my heart is the fight against corruption.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The Serious Fraud Office (SFO) has been reengineered and named the Economic and Organised Crime Office (EOCO) with prosecutorial powers.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Ghanaians watched a shocking expose of corrupt activities and practices involving revenue collection at the Tema Port.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: We are not taking lightly the potential threats to the security of the oil and gas industry.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The government has taken steps to enable the Ghana Navy maintain a strong maritime presence.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The Ghana Air Force is also being re-equipped with transport aircrafts, surveillance planes and helicopters.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: These will enhance the capacity of the Ghana Armed Forces to ensure the country‚Äôs territorial integrity and provide safe sea passage to all legitimate traffic while combating illegal activities including, bunkering, drug trafficking, poaching and pair trawling.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The Ghana Police Service with the help of other security agencies have clamped down heavily on crime ‚Äì especially armed robbery.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The armed robbers are no longer operating with impunity.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: This year, with the recruitment of an additional 3,200 personnel to beef-up the Police Service, crime will be fought with extra zeal.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: I expect the Police Administration to seek external help and collaboration where necessary regarding unsolved murders.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: I ordered the re-opening of investigations into serial killing of women which occurred in the period 1998-2000.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Fire outbreaks continue to cause havoc throughout the country especially in the markets.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: I expect District, Municipal and Metropolitan Chief Executives to mount a serious check on violations of regulations and bye-laws and remove unauthorized structures which obstruct access to markets, drains and fire hydrants.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The Fire Service is expected to take delivery of a fairly large number of fire-fighting engines and gear for its personnel this year.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: I have put the security agencies on red alert and they are under strict instructions to deal decisively within the ambit of the law with anybody or group of persons who will attempt to disturb the peace and stability of this country.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: I pledged to wage a concerted and relentless war against the drug menace.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: I have decided that a full-scale investigation into the disappearance of cocaine from the Police vault as well as the 77 parcels of cocaine which entered Ghana's territorial waters aboard the MV Benjamin vessel and mysteriously got missing should be re-opened.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: I believe that the majority of Ghanaians are happy not to be waking up to daily stories of cocaine here, cocaine there and cocaine everywhere.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: We will continue to make Ghana an unattractive destination for the narcotics trade and will collaborate fully with cross-border and other foreign operatives to flush out the drug barons and their couriers.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: When it comes to discipline on our roads, we cannot produce a script that we can be proud of.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: I have given strict instructions to the Ghana Police and other law enforcement agencies to rigidly apply the appropriate sanctions in dealing with all who fall foul of traffic laws.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: I have instructed the Driver Vehicle Licensing Authority (DVLA) to conduct an immediate review of internal processes for the acquisition of licenses.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The Attorney-General‚Äôs office is to review and strengthen legislation to ensure drivers and owners of broken down vehicles that stay on the roads and cause accidents and deaths pay the price for it.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: It is however not enough to believe or proclaim, but rather to practice one‚Äôs belief in an acceptable and peaceful manner.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Political stability is the gift of political discipline by all actors.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Those of us in leadership positions bear the heaviest burden in ensuring that our actions and utterances do not incite lawlessness and damage our sense of community.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The media has a huge responsibility in the effort we must all make to encourage rational exchanges among reasonable people with different views.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Just because you have the right to say something does not mean you should.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The draft Broadcasting Bill has been too long on the drawing board.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: It is time to consider seriously its enactment to help control the excesses that sometimes characterize exchanges in the electronic media.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: I believe we have abundant experience and expertise in this country in the art of diplomacy and peacekeeping.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: We will draw on this expertise in our common desire to help our brothers and sisters in Cote d‚ÄôIvoire find a lasting solution to the political impasse there.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: This is not the moment for anyone with the interest of Ghana at heart to start beating war drums.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Ghana will continue to participate and support peace-keeping initiatives across the world to the extent that our resources and capacity will permit.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Africa will welcome Southern Sudan as a new country following the conclusive results of the referendum held recently.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The Government of Sudan deserves commendation for the co-operative spirit with which it has handled the process.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: I am confident that the challenges notwithstanding, the policy choices and concrete development programme of this Administration will raise Ghana to the next level with its promise of a better future in a Better Ghana.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Our pre-occupation has been to restore the economy to good health, improve living conditions, rehabilitate and expand infrastructure, as well as strengthen democratic institutions and practice.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Today, in addition to cocoa, gold and other natural resources we also have oil.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: I will remain focused and continue to serve this country with a clear conscience as we begin the 3rd year of this Administration.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Let no one think that inciting or priming others for violence is the way to determine the outcome of elections.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The economy is full of promise and in terms of development; we are making substantial progress even though there is still a lot of work to be done.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Over the past three years that I have been President, much has been achieved in pursuance of our ‚ÄúBetter Ghana‚Äù Agenda.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Even though we have experienced internal and external constraints, we have reason to be hopeful of Ghana‚Äôs future.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: A recent report by the World Bank has alerted developing countries of further economic shocks this year and the need for contingency planning.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: We are therefore watching developments in the global economy with hope and apprehension.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Hope, because the easing of the global crisis is likely to give rise to economic stability and expansion that will impact on our economy; apprehension, because further weakening of the Highly Indebted Rich Countries (HIRCs) and of the global economy will have serious economic consequences not least on commodity prices.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Notwithstanding the global economic uncertainties, this administration has continued to make progress in the management of the national economy.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Under my watch, Ghana has recorded the highest ever growth rate in the annals of our nation‚Äôs history with a provisional growth rate approaching 14%.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: In my 2011 State of the Nation Address, I described inflation as the worst economic nightmare any country can go through because it breeds economic and financial difficulties and imposes hardships on the most vulnerable.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: I stated then that our success in confronting inflation in the previous year was notable; the challenge was to remain on course.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: We recorded the most sustained single digit rates of inflation in decades, with the rate of inflation of 8.55% for 2011 being the lowest in 42 years since 1970.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: As at the end of September, the budget deficit was 2% of GDP as compared to 14.5% of GDP in 2008.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: With the exception of the level of the budget deficit which was higher than anticipated, we have managed to attain the macroeconomic projections contained in the 2008 NDC Manifesto for a Better Ghana.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The credit belongs to all Ghanaians and to the Government as the direct managers of the economy as well as Parliament as its monitors.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The positive economic indicators we have achieved have resulted in increased investor confidence in the economy.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: A fortnight ago the Ghana Investment Promotion Centre released figures showing an increase in projects registered at the GIPC amounting to over $7billion in foreign direct investment.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: There is still a lot of work to be done and I am confident that these Organisations will not let the nation down.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Our achievements in managing inflation, budget deficit and realizing high GDP growth rates have reflected in the progress made in many key areas of national development.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: A snapshot of the education sector provides a good example of how far we have come within the short time span of 3 years.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: In the city of Accra for example efforts have been made to bring an end to the school shift system which has been a drawback in the fight for quality education.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Several classroom structures have been constructed providing accommodation for hundreds of pupils who now benefit from a full day classroom teaching.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Contracts for the construction of over 1,700 classroom blocks for schools under trees have been awarded throughout the country.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: As regards the second cycle level of the educational strata, about 672 emergency classroom blocks and dormitories are in various phases of completion nationwide.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Indeed, on my nationwide tour last year, I commissioned many of such completed projects.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: In line with our social democratic principles, we aim at making secondary education accessible to every Ghanaian child of school going age by 2016.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The completion of the emergency classroom blocks will make it possible to increase second cycle enrolment.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Between 2013 and 2015, we intend establishing additional community second cycle schools throughout the length and breadth of the country, particularly in under-served districts.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: So far, these programmes have made a great impact on youth employment in the informal sector of the economy.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: It is expected that the shift of the NYEP focus from traditional paid modules to trade and vocation modules will encourage self-employment.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Madam Speaker, pursuance to a pledge made last year, the School of Fisheries at Anomabo, a satellite college of University of Cape Coast, is underway.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Also, a head office building for the Ghana Academy of Arts and Sciences is under construction.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Important changes have taken place in the communication industry in Ghana.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: In July last year, Mobile Number Portability was introduced offering choice to mobile phone subscribers.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: A lot of preparation on digital broadcasting migration has been going on and we are on course to switch over from analogue to digital in December 2014 ahead of the 2015 deadline set for all countries.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: So far close to 60,000 laptops have been distributed and it is expected that by June this year, the number would have doubled.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: This surely is good news for our students who hitherto had to write their Basic Education Certificate Examination ICT papers without having ever seen or touched the key pad of a computer.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Before Parliament rose from its third and final meeting last year, the bills on the establishment of the University of Health and Allied Sciences in the Volta Region and the University of Energy and Natural Resources in the Brong Ahafo Region, were passed.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Work is seriously in progress as regards putting in place the needed infrastructure for staff and students.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Indeed, the Governing Councils of the two universities have been inaugurated and it is expected that admissions will begin when the new academic year begins sometime in September.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: A lot has also been achieved in terms of improved infrastructural facilities for effective teaching and learning in the existing public tertiary institutions.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: In the particular case of the University of Development Studies, we have made available funds for the expansion of infrastructural facilities and procurement of laboratory equipment and other projects.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: In the area of Human Resource Training and Development in foreign universities since 2009, the GETFUND has been providing funding in anticipation of employment in the following areas: 1. Emerging Oil & Gas Sector 2. The University of Health & Allied Sciences (Faculty) 3. The University of Energy and Renewable Natural Resources (Faculty) 4. Other Public Universities 5. The broader National Economy.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: This Administration has been concerned about job creation and its importance for the growth of the economy and the development of the nation.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Indeed, the second pillar of the National Democratic Congress (NDC) Manifesto addresses the building of a Strong and Resilient Economy as well as the Creation of Jobs.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: It is on this account that as soon as this Government settled, we organized a special Cabinet Retreat to deal solely with this vital subject.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: It would be recalled Ministers, as leaders of their sectors, were directed to work with the leadership of the private sector to find innovative ways of creating jobs outside the traditional employment avenues.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: I can say with confidence that many jobs have since been created outside the non-traditional areas of employment.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Of course, many have also been employed via the traditional employment avenues.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: With the expected heavy infrastructure expansion as well as the building of the allied petrochemical industries associated with our oil and gas find, I can safely project that many more jobs will be created by the time the tenure of this Government comes to an end.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: True to our commitment to modernizing agriculture, the Government has increased the stock of Rice Combine Harvesters, maize harvesters; additional grain-cocoon storage facilities and bore holes for agricultural purposes where none existed.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Agricultural Mechanization Service Centers have also been established.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: As a result of targeted interventions in the agricultural sector, we have recorded significant increases in rice, yam and maize production.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Our cotton farmers in the Northern Regions can attest to how far we have gone in reviving the cotton industry while Government intervention has resulted in a sizeable increase in cotton production.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Between 2009 and 2011, Government has rehabilitated several irrigation dams in the three northern regions, the Greater Accra, Volta, Ashanti, and Brong Ahafo regions.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: With the completion of a master plan for irrigation development, the first phase of the Accra Plains Irrigation Project covering an area of about 11,000 hectares will begin this year.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: For the first time ever, Ghana produced over one million tonnes of cocoa in 2011.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Our output last year was over 50% the output in 2008 which was 680,000 tonnes.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: In terms of the percentage of the world cocoa price that is paid to the farmer, we have out-performed every government in our history.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: At an average world market price of US$2,450.00 per tonne in January 2012, we are paying the cocoa farmer about 80% of the world market price.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: A new shea nut factory has been established at Buipe in the Northern Region, to process sheanuts for export.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The factory is expected to process close to 40,000 tons a year.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Government has already inaugurated the National Steering Committee to formulate programmes and strategies for growing and sustaining the industry.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The floor price for purchases at the farm gate has been fixed to ensure that the farmers are not shortchanged.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Government through COCOBOD has launched a 6-year cocoa re-planting programme to rehabilitate old cocoa farms in Ghana.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The programme entails the production of elite cocoa hybrid seedlings for distribution to farmers free of charge to be used in replanting.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The main objective of the programmes is to create employment opportunities for our youth in cocoa growing communities throughout the period of the programme and assist them to acquire the relevant techniques and skills in cocoa production under the Youth in Agriculture Programme.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Another objective is to encourage under-producing farmers to expand their acreage and increase their yield.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: This administration has taken steps to enforce the Fisheries Regulations and protect fisheries resources.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: To this end some patrol vessels have been acquired and will soon be commissioned.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Implementation of a Fisheries and Aquaculture Development Plan will begin this year.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: A turnkey fish processing plant at Elmina is expected to commence this year.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: We pledged in our Manifesto to focus on the production, distribution and supply of water taking into account the needs of the poor.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: We also pledged to build and expand a number of water plants nationwide.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Since 2009, we have constructed hundreds of boreholes fitted with hand pumps, hand dug wells with hand pumps and piped water systems throughout the country.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: I have directed that at least 20,000 boreholes be constructed nationwide over the next four years.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The Government has absorbed the 5% contribution by communities to the capital cost of construction of rural water systems in rural communities.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The Kpong Water Expansion Project is expected to add 40million gallons of water daily to the Accra-Tema Metropolis.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The many interventions we have made in the urban water sector are expected to bring about an increase in coverage from the present 62% to 80% by 2015.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: This Government inherited a total electricity generation capacity of around 1,800 megawatts in 2009.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: We have since installed an additional 376 megawatts to the generation capacity.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Additional capacity will be added this year through the expansion of the Takoradi International Company (TICO), the planned completion of the Bui project, the development of the Kpone Thermal Power Plant; and the completion of the Tema Osono Power Project.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: By the end of 2013, power generation should reach about 3,300Mw, an over 80% increase in the generation capacity we came to meet.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The national electricity transmission system that we inherited was saddled with over-aged and obsolete equipment, overloads, high losses, low voltage and evacuation constraints, among others.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: These have included the completion of transmission networks and substation projects at Buipe in the Northern Region; Kpando, Ho and Asiekpe in the Volta Region; Sunyani and Techiman in the Brong Ahafo Region; Obuasi and Kumasi in the Ashanti Region; Tema and Accra in the Greater Accra Region; Winneba in the Central Region and Takoradi in the Western Region.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: In all honesty, the phenomenon of ‚Äúdumsor, dumsor‚Äù is not as bad as it used to be at the time we took over the management of the affairs of state and it is our determination to continue to work to make the situation much better than it is currently.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: From 2009 to date, under the various rural electrification projects, over 1,700 communities have been connected to the national grid.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: We are aiming to extend electricity to a further 4,000 or more communities covering all the regions in the country.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: I would like to mention that the programme to provide street lights to all regional capitals is proceeding according to plan and will in future be extended to cover all municipal and district capitals in the country.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: At the end of last year, Ghana had earned a total of US$444,124,724 from the sale of the Ghana Group‚Äôs 4liftingstotalling 3,930,189 barrels of crude oil.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: We have made and will continue to make full public disclosure of all oil liftings and revenues accrued even as we hope for success in on-going oil and gas exploration in other areas.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The appointment and inauguration of the Public Interest Committee under the Chairmanship of an eminent Ghanaian is to demonstrate the Government‚Äôs intention to enhance transparency and accountability.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Once again, this Government has demonstrated its commitment to a Ghana-first approach to the handling of national affairs wherever the national interest can better be served that way.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: There have been some challenges in production at the Jubilee Oil Field.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: As a result, production estimates have been scaled down pending the completion of a remedial programme.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The Ministry of Energy and the newly established Petroleum Commission are positively keeping a close eye on the matter.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The Ghana National Gas Company Limited (Ghana Gas) which is charged with responsibility to build, own and operate infrastructure required for gathering, processing, transporting and marketing of natural gas resources in the country has commenced business in earnest especially in the area of the development of gas infrastructure.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The completion of the project will stimulate diversification of the national economy.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: In my State of the Nation Address last year, I informed this House of the bold and courageous steps we had taken to implement the new pay policy, popularly referred to as the Single Spine Pay Policy (SSPP).

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: As at that time, just about 11% of public service employees had been migrated onto the Single Spine Salary Structure (SSSS).

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: In the 2011 Action Year, over 80% of public service employees were migrated onto the SSSS and the process is expected to be completed within the year.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The implementation of the SSSS has not been without challenges.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: In my first State of the Nation address in 2009, I indicated that SADA and CEDECOM will be used to address the peculiar poverty related problems in the three Northern regions and the Central region respectively.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: In the intervening period, the law that formally establishes the Savannah Accelerated Development Authority has been passed and the Authority has been formally established.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: CEDECOM is the shell around which the Western Corridor Development Authority will be created.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The creations of the other Development Authorities that I mentioned in my 2011 Address are receiving very active attention at the NDPC and will follow in the course of the year.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The National Health Insurance Scheme continues to grow with utilization rising from about 600,000 in 2005 to over 17.5million as at December 2011.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: There is the urgent need for dialogue and consensus on financing of the NHIS to ensure sustainability.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Currently, measures are being implemented for cost containment through improved provider payment systems.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Meanwhile, for better customer orientation the scheme has planned to start a call centre to make it more user-friendly.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Our plan to improve access to quality healthcare is very much on course via a number of on-going projects nationwide.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Indeed, a number of new health facilities have been completed within the last three years and will soon be put to use, notable of which is the Winneba Municipal Hospital.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Significant progress has been made on the Tamale Teaching Hospital rehabilitation project.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Government is also strengthening the capacity of existing Regional, District Hospitals, and Polyclinics.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Five polyclinics will be completed by the end of June in Wechiau, Babille, Ko, Lambussie and Hain, all in the upper west region.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Government‚Äôs intervention in the deplorable state of the Korle-bu Teaching hospital has led to the procurement of life support equipment and new oxygen plants, the installation of which will soon commence.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Under the National Medical Equipment Replacement Project, Government is providing life support equipment, and medical imaging in selected District Hospitals nationwide as well as re-equipping radiology departments in the teaching and regional hospitals with state of the art Magnetic Resonance Imagers, and CT scanners.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: These centers are also receiving mammography units to make breast cancer screening routine.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Equipment will be supplied and installed in district hospitals as well as health centers across the country.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: As a matter of fact, state-of-the-art Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) machines are currently being installed at the Komfo Anokye and Tamale Teaching Hospitals.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: It is expected that in the course of the year, MRI machines will be installed at the Volta and Central Regional Hospitals.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Basic Obstetric equipment have also been supplied and installed in selected district hospitals and health centers across the country as part of efforts at reducing maternal mortality.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The National Ambulance Service will take delivery of 160 ambulances this year to augment the existing fleet.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Apart from health structures and equipments, we have established new Health Assistant Training Schools, Nurses Training Schools, as well as Midwifery schools in various parts of the country to train more health personnel.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The last guinea worm case in Ghana was reported in May 2010 at Diare in the Northern Region.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: In 2012, we will intensify our disease surveillance to make sure that guinea worm is not re-introduced into Ghana and to also prepare Ghana for certification by the World Health Organization as a country free of guinea worm.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: As at January 2009, the Tetteh Quarshie-Madina road was about 30% complete.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: As at January 2009, funds were still being mobilized for the Madina-Pantang road.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The Achimota-Ofankor road is now over 80% complete

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The Koforidua bypass has been completed and is in use so has the Kumasi Techiman road

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The Nsawam bypass, the Nkawkaw bypass, the Oforikrom-Asokwa bypass, the first phase of the Sogakope-Adidome-Ho-Fume and the Bamboi-Tinga road are all nearing completion.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Reconstruction of the Asikuma Junction-Hohoe road, the 147 kilometre Fulfulso-Sawla road, the 60-kilometre Assin Praso-Bekwai road, the Dodi Papaso-Nkwanta road and the Nkwanta-Oti Damanko road is on course.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Because 2012 is an election year, it goes without saying that our security institutions must be in a state of readiness to ensure peace and calm before, during, and after the elections.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The Police, Military and other institutions charged with law enforcement will have the fullest support of Government to act decisively and fairly.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Our commitment to ensure the safety of Ghanaians is as strong as ever.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Over the past years there has been a reduction in major crimes such as armed robbery, car snatching, highway robbery, narcotics and murder and the law enforcement agents are under strict instructions to sustain the arrest of narcotic traffickers and their collaborators.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: We have increased the strength of the Police Service by over 4,000 and at the same time taken steps to modernize its forensic facilities to assist in crime prevention and detection.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: A large quantity of vehicles, communication gadgets, bulletproof vests have been provided to boost operational efficiency of the Police.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The Ghana Immigration Service is expected to complete installation of Digital Border Surveillance System at strategically selected Border control points.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: This around-the-clock monitoring equipment seeks to enhance border security especially in the face of new sub-regional threats of religious and ethnic nature.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The Ghana Armed Forces, in the last three years, is not in the near-moribund state it used to be before January 2009.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: A lot of acquisition has been made in equipment and hardware for the Navy and the Air Force.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: We will leave no stone unturned in our effort to develop a credible defence system capable of protecting our Oil and Gas Industry and our territorial integrity as a whole.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: On the youth front; through the Better Ghana Caravan Project we are focusing on activities in the priority areas of employable skills, Youth Health and Sexuality education, drug use and substance abuse education, conflict prevention, management and resolution.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) which had suspended the Ghana Olympic Committee (GOC) lifted the ban last August paving the way for Ghana‚Äôs participation in the upcoming London 2012 Olympic Games.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Ghana is to play host to the second ECOWAS Games in June this year.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: At the 10th All Africa Games held in Maputo, Mozambique in September last year, Team Ghana put up the best performance ever by winning 19 medals.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The National U-23 male football team and their U-20 female counterparts won gold and silver respectively at the Games.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: In the course of last year, the Senior National Football team, the Black Stars was rated 14th in the FIFA world ranking and 1st in Africa.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: That has so far been Ghana‚Äôs best ranking in world football.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The Black Stars did not lift the African Cup as anticipated; better luck to all of us next time.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The Job 600 project will surely be completed this year and ready for your occupation next year.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: I am confident that I will be the first President to address you at a time when you will be working from the comfort of your new offices.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: This year, I hope to work with Honourable members to review three initiatives that I announced will be instituted in the course of my Presidency.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: These are the assignment of National Service personnel as Research Assistants to MPs; the construction of constituency duty offices for Honourable members; and the establishment of an MPs‚Äô Constituency Development Fund separate and apart from the District Assemblies Common Fund.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Last year, I noted in my address that the work of the Constitutional Review Commission was on schedule.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: I also noted that all governance reforms must ultimately take their ethos from the Constitution Review Process.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: I am happy to report that the Commission has since presented its Report to me ahead of schedule and I have identified a Technical Implementation Committee to assist Cabinet develop the white paper and begin with the implementation of the recommendations without delay.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Let me state here and now that I remain undaunted by attempts to thwart the fight against corruption by legal and technical means.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: I do not care whose ox is gored when it comes to the fight against corruption and neither will I be off-tracked by all the sideline comments that are being made to befuddle the hardcore issues.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: The fate of the abortive Ghana@50 Commission prosecutions stayed my hand in going the route of appointing a Presidential Commission to re-open investigations into the disappearance of cocaine from the Police vault as well as the 77 parcels of cocaine that got mysteriously missing from the MV Benjamin that I announced in my Address last year.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: We have since identified what went wrong with the Ghana@50 Commission and we will address it and definitely begin the cocaine investigations this year.

speaker: H.E. John Evans Atta Mills
claims: Indeed, as I speak, the National Security has in its custody a very key player in the case of the 77 parcels of supposedly missing cocaine.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Our recent Presidential and Parliamentary elections have been adjudged by both domestic and international observers as by far the most credible, transparent, free and fair since 1992.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: The Electoral Commission has organized six successful elections since our return to constitutional rule in 1992.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: They have conferred victory where victory was due without fear or favour in the critical periods of 2000, 2008 and 2012.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Our Electoral Commission has earned, in the process, an enviable reputation as arguably one of the best electoral institutions on the African continent.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Ghana has witnessed impressive development in the last two decades.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: There have been improvements in roads and social infrastructure across the length and breadth of this country.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Health facilities have been expanded and access improved, and so have educational institutions with the private sector playing a pivotal role.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: our quest to build an equitable society in which the productive capacities of our people are tapped for national development will come to naught if we do not give our children sound, meaningful and relevant education.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Any nation whose people do not have the required level of education will be left behind.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: It is also the objective of this government, to eliminate the remaining schools under trees by the end of 2016.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: The school-feeding programme will be progressively expanded to all public basic schools in rural communities to satisfy the basic nutritional needs of the pupils.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Paramount among these is a lack of access occasioned by inadequate space and facilities for the large number of qualified Junior High School graduates.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: To address the limitations imposed on access to secondary education we will, over the next four years, construct a total of two hundred new community day Senior High schools, giving priority to Districts, which currently lack such schools.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: The relevance of improved health services cannot be over emphasized.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: A sick population cannot generate the productivity needed to maintain the acceleration of our economy.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Presently, our healthcare system still has personnel deficits and service deficiencies despite the facility expansion and human capacity development programmes we have been implementing.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: This will be consistent with our record over the last four years.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Our goal is to ensure a more efficient, expanded and sustainable delivery.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: A few weeks ago we had to endure the painful experience of missing out on our much-cherished dream of winning a fifth African Cup of Nations title.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Our Black Stars exited the just ended AFCON competition at the semi-final stage through the lottery of penalty.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: I recall how barely a year ago, our beloved late President Mills standing before this august house in his last sessional address, urged our football authorities to take seriously the issue of penalty taking by our teams as it has often been our nemesis in major competitions.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: What many appreciated as a humorous comment turned out to be prophetic as the same problem came to haunt us at the just ended AFCON competition.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Another major tournament we need to prepare for is the Olympic games in 2016.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: SADA has agriculture as a key part of its agenda.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: In the spirit of Public-Private Partnership, SADA has facilitated partnerships to establish three agro processing factories- a sheanut processing factory at Buipe, a rice mill at Nyankpala near Tamale and a vegetable oil mill at Tamale.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: The Produce Buying Company is currently raising the capital to begin sheanut purchases to feed the factory.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: This will benefit tens of thousands of poor women in the savannah zone of this country.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Outgrowers are being registered to meet the requirements of these factories.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: In 2011, SADA supported 6,000 farming families Last year SADA registered and supported another 16,000 farmers this year with farm inputs, including fertilizers, improved seeds and tractor services for land preparation services.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: SADA through its greening the Northern Savannah ecological zone agenda, has partnered with a private sector group to grow and nurture 5 million trees in the next 12 months.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: The implementation framework for the Authority is currently under development.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: The economy of Ghana has over a period of more than two decades consistently witnessed a positive growth rate.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: This back-to-back growth registered from 1986 culminated in the attainment of lower middle-income status in the year 2010.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: This positive performance was taken to a whole new level in the year 2011 when our country registered what is believed to be probably the highest growth rate in the world- a whopping 14.4 percent growth in GDP.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Since then our country has maintained its ranking among the 10 fastest growing economies in the world.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Inflation that for so long had been in double digits, has for the first time in our history remained within single digit for over thirty long months.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Apart from the first half of 2012, when the cedi experienced serious pressures resulting from a huge balance of trade deficit, the currency has continued to enjoy relative stability.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: This relative stability has been boosted by the relatively strong foreign reserves of the country that have increased significantly from about $2billion at the beginning of 2009 to the current $5.5billion.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: The National Petroleum Authority recently announced adjustments in the prices of petroleum products to realign the distortions in the pricing of petroleum products.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: These distortions had resulted in a situation where Government had to shell out about GHC150 million to the Bulk Distribution Companies (BDCs) to compensate them for losses sustained in the supply of petroleum products.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: The net effect was also that because of the wide disparity in price between us and our neighbours, many unscrupulous people found a new occupation in smuggling the products across our borders for sale.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: We would rationalize the use of government vehicles and fuel in the next few weeks.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: I have given the Chief of Staff appropriate directives on this matter.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: We will discuss with auto companies a scheme to enable Senior Public servants to buy on hire purchase their own vehicles and curtail the reliance on the use of State vehicles.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: We are also taking strict measures to curtail MDAs spending beyond their budgetary allocations and new mechanisms of strict monitoring will be announced by the Minister of Finance in the 2013 budget.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: The Ghana Revenue Authority and other agencies have been tasked to help raise tax and non-tax revenues to levels that benefit our emerging Lower Middle-Income Country status.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: We will plug the leakages and raise Ghana‚Äôs ratio of revenue to GDP from the current meager 16% to above 20%.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Comparative levels with other lower middle income countries are Kenya 24% and Senegal 22%.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Ghana improved from the 92nd position in 2009 to the 63rd in 2012 on the World Bank‚Äôs ‚ÄúEase of Doing Business Index‚Äù.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: I have already inaugurated the Private Sector Advisory Council under my chairmanship, and decisive steps are underway to deepen the implementation of the Private Sector Development Strategy (PSDS) II, covering all major aspects of private sector development.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: We will use Government‚Äôs significant procurement power to benefit the Ghanaian Private Sector.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: The process of modernization, involving the use of improved seed varieties, greater access to tractor services and training of peasant and small holder farmers on productivity enhancements, has resulted in dramatic increases in maize, rice and cassava production in the last four years.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: These will be expanded with an additional 2,000 tractors, improved seed support and fertilizer subsidies, especially for the poorest farmers.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Total land under irrigation throughout the country will be substantially increased as a result of new initiatives on the Accra Plains and the Savannah zone, under a new World Bank facility on commercial agriculture development.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: This will allow for all year round farming and will enhance Ghana‚Äôs food security.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: These two projects are expected to bring some 80,000 hectares of land under irrigation in the Northern belt.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: A more coherent focus on fisheries and aquaculture development has been initiated, with the designation of a new Ministry for Fisheries and Aquaculture Development and the imminent establishment of a college of Fisheries planned for Anomabo as a department of the University of Cape Coast.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: our focus is to work towards achieving sustainable production of the historic one million tonnes of cocoa.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Work is ongoing on a $1.2 billion ammonia-urea based fertilizer processing plant with an annual capacity of one million tons in Nyankrom in the Shama District of the Western Region.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: This is an initiative between the Ghana and Indian Governments with a potential for boosting trade, jobs creation, and increased agricultural productivity.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Ghana was listed by the International Telecommunication Union (ITU) as one of the top ten most dynamic performing countries in ICT-for-development in 2011.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Indeed, telephone subscription in Ghana reached close to 26million as of December 2012, representing more than double the number as of December 2008.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: The work on the Eastern Corridor Rural Fibre Optic backbone network project will be accelerated to add 584 kilometres of optic fibre stretching from Ho to Bawku and linking 70 towns enroute to improve the quality of communications services.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: We shall commence the distribution of Four Hundred Thousand (400,000) laptop computers to schools and students.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Work is soon commencing on the Northern segment of the Eastern Corridor road, stretching from Oti Damanko to Nakpanduri.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: This year we expect to bring to a significant point of completion many of the ongoing road projects including the Kpando- Worawora- Dambai, Asankragwa- Enchi, Navrongo- Tumu and the Achimota- Ofankor, Madina- Pantang, Nsawam- Suhum-Apedwa, La- Teshie, Dansoman and the Apaaso- Kintampo roads.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Others are the Sefwi Bekwai- Eshiem- Asankragwa, Bomfa Junction- Asiwa- Bekwai, Tetteh Quarshie-Madina and the Berekum- Sampa roads.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: COCOBOD is funding the reshaping, spot improvements and upgrading of gravel roads to bituminous surfaces in cocoa, coffee and sheanut producing areas.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: In the course of this year, and under the policy on public private partnerships, feasibility studies will commence on the dualization of the Accra- Cape Coast- Takoradi road, and the rehabilitation and expansion of the Accra- Tema motorway.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: New interchanges are also planned for the Tema end of the motorway and the Kasoa-Bawjiase intersection.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Work will commence this year too on a new interchange at the Kwame Nkrumah Circle.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: It is also my hope that the project for the PPP in respect of the multi-carriage Accra-Kumasi Highway will be approved by Parliament for work to commence this year.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: There has been tremendous work in this sector and I recall my meeting with the railway workers at the ‚ÄòBottom Tree‚Äô in Sekondi.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: I can confidently say to them today, that as we continue with our railway sector development programme there will be significant signs of improvement within the next three years.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Government believes the private sector has a role to play in the on-going modernization of the rail sector, an example being the rehabilitation of the Accra-Tema, Kumasi-Ejisu, the Accra Nsawam and Takoradi-Kojokrom rail networks.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Available data shows that passenger traffic through our International Airport has more than quadrupled in the last 3 years.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Domestic passenger traffic on the other hand has increased ten-fold.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: The pollution of our environment and especially our beachfronts is depressing.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Government will in the next three years work with all stakeholders to ensure that the National Housing Policy document is not only finalized and approved by both Cabinet and Parliament; but also, work feverishly to ensure that relevant legislation is put in place to provide the necessary foundation as well as legal framework for implementation.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Government will this year initiate a pilot scheme to combine social housing with improved sanitation and water supply.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: This will particularly concentrate on the dense urban slums where the phenomenon of safe sanitation and waste disposal are very weak.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: I am deeply concerned about how the challenges in the housing sector, have led to exorbitant rents that do not only violate our rent law but also suffocate the average Ghanaian.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Water supply is currently precarious in some communities including significant parts of Accra.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: This is in spite of the several efforts we have been making to improve the supply of good drinking water, especially to Ghanaians.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: It is worth noting however that these efforts are beginning to yield some results.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: The situation however requires massive investment in new water delivery infrastructure and timely maintenance like the ongoing works at the Kpong headworks.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: This sanitation management effort has helped to address part of the waste disposal problem.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: The Task Force experience is now being reviewed in order to engage all the stakeholders, including the District Assemblies, in a more sustained and concerted effort to rid our country of the unsightly rubbish heaps that are threatening the health of our communities.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: The start of the CONTI project in Accra financed by the US EXIM will see significant improvement in flood control and solid and liquid waste management in the capital city.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: This problem has been fully investigated and we have concluded that there is an unacceptable collusion between some Ghanaians and these foreigners to circumvent our laws.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Millions of Ghanaians and businesses are today experiencing very erratic and frustrating electricity supply.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Work on the WAGPI is now planned for completion in April 2013.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Ghana continues to exhibit strong leadership in democratic governance, which makes us the envy of many nations.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: we have just come out of an historic election which witnessed progressive reforms including the use of a biometric voters register and biometric verification for voting which has been acclaimed by both domestic and international observers as free, fair and transparent.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: The independence of the judiciary would be upheld and we would work to improve conditions of work of the judiciary.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: We will work with the Judicial Council to continue the process of providing new and more modern court rooms and provide the instruments and equipment to facilitate the work of the judges.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: We will guarantee freedom of worship as enshrined in our constitution and continue to promote peaceful coexistence of all religions in our country.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: The ‚ÄòJob 600‚Äô project, which will ensure that Members of Parliament can operate from descent offices, is almost complete.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: MPs can expect to be furnished with laptops with full Internet connectivity to facilitate communication between their offices and constituents as promised in the NDC manifesto.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: I have therefore instructed the Cabinet office to ensure that Cabinet meetings rotate between Accra and the Regional capitals.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: By this, millions of our citizens outside Accra will have the opportunity each month to witness and participate in the process of decision-making directly.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: The Broadcasting Bill has been on the drawing board for a long time.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: We shall also support the National Media Commission to enact the needed Regulations that will establish an organizational framework and standards to ensure balance, fairness, access, opportunity and objectivity in the media.

claims: Access to the establishment of Community radio will be improved to allow millions more to benefit from the unique attributes of this medium.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
