speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: We would push for critical reforms in the AGs department.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: I will implement the Freedom of Information Act as soon as it is passed by Parliament.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Our commitment to the fight against corruption remains unshakeable.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: We would streamline and root out the rot that has become associated with the alienation of public lands.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: We will pursue the programme for the legislative conversion of the Narcotics Control Board (NACOB) into an autonomous Commission.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: A worrying trend in our crime indices is increasing cases of rape and defilement.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: In many cases families, religious leaders, traditional rulers and sometimes public officials intervene to cover up and resolve these cases at home.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: I am instructing the IGP, DOVVSU, GCSP to work together to ensure that all of such cases are brought to justice.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: In this regard we will build a second military hospital in Kumasi and upgrade the medical stations in the various barracks.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: I intend to begin a new round of bringing to closure some of the protracted chieftaincy conflicts in the north.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: I call for the cooperation of all my compatriots in these areas to give peace a chance.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: We can only succeed in turning around the fortunes of the 3 Northern regions if we have an atmosphere of peace and security.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: We have recently joined with ECOWAS in seeking a permanent peaceful resolution of the conflict in Mali, by contributing a modest detachment of our armed forces to participate in the African-led force operating in Mali, AFISMA.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: I wish once again to assure any refugees on our territory that they are welcome guests as long as they do not use Ghana as a base to destabilize the Governments in their home countries.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Ghana will continue to take all necessary measures, in cooperation with relevant international agencies, to fight against international terrorism, money laundering, narcotics and human trafficking.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: These profound words have as much meaning today as they were five decades ago.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: It is a challenge to us to work together to bring honour to our country and its people.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: We are a nation of diverse cultures and religious beliefs; there is a tremendous amount of beauty in our diversity.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: We are determined to deliver on the development goals, which I have outlined.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: We have objectives to meet and the expectations of our people to fulfill; our people expect to see results, whether it is in the delivery of water, electricity, healthcare or sanitation services.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Political office holders including Ministers of State, Metropolitan, Municipal and District Chief Executives, CEOs of public institutions and middle and lower management personnel will be required to exhibit a high sense of responsibility and diligently execute their mandate to meet the needs of the ordinary Ghanaian.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Ghana is a nation in transition.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: We are on the cusp of many exciting new opportunities.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: We are in the midst of change.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Without change, Ghana cannot grow.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Change is what will propel us forward, as a nation, to all that lies ahead.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: These new opportunities will enable us to transform ourselves from a lower middle-income, import-dependent, developing country to a proud and robust, self-sufficient middle-income nation.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: We have been here before, as a nation.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Ghana was created through change, a movement of the people in support of their collective vision.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: Ghana went on to influence change on the African continent and in effect, the course of the world.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: We are a nation of 24 million.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama

claims: Wealth disparity is of great concern to my government.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama

claims: It is this government‚Äôs vision to extend quality health care to all our people irrespective of one‚Äôs status in society or geographical location.

claims: Government is pursuing the vision of bringing healthcare to the doorsteps of our people, in even the remotest of locations.

claims: We have been engaged in an aggressive rollout of Community Health Improvement Compounds [CHPS].

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: My colleagues and I in the Executive branch of Government have taken a voluntary ten percent (10%) cut in salaries.

claims: Our policy is to provide every district with a modern health facility.

claims: The newly constructed Tarkwa Hospital has been equipped and is now open for use.

claims: Work is ongoing on twelve (12) new district hospitals, including Dodowa, Sekondi, Fomena and Garu-Tempane.

claims: Financing for an extra nine (9) are being concluded.

claims: Under the National Medical Equipment Replacement Programme, modern equipment has been supplied to forty (40) district hospitals.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama

claims: Our prevalence rate for HIV and AIDS continues to decline and currently stands at 1.37%.

claims: Education has proven to be the most effective tool in the battle against the spread of HIV/AIDS.

claims: Government has been working to improve the quality of education, especially at the basic level.

claims: Government has been working to improve the quality of education, especially at the basic level.

claims: In many regions there is an excess of teachers in urban and peri-urban areas, but in the rural and other deprived communities, teachers are often in short supply.

claims: Ghana has been successful in achieving the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) on universal primary education.

claims: Existing secondary schools have a capacity to absorb only 60% of the students who qualify from Junior High School.

claims: There are some schools with as many as 3000 students.

claims: The 2015 budget allocates to the education sector about 6.7 billion Ghana Cedis.

claims: We will this year spend over 3 billion Ghana Cedis on the health sector.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: The provision of modern diagnostic and treatment equipment under the National Medical Equipment Replacement Programme has been expanded to cover 150 hospitals across the country.

claims: The St. Joseph Hospital in Nkwanta, the Adidome Hospital, the Dodo Pepesu Hospital and the Jasikan Government Hospital, all in the Volta Region have also benefitted from the National Medical Equipment Replacement Programme.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: We have made significant progress in reducing the incidence of HIV/AIDS and are on track to achieve virtual elimination of mother to child transmission.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama

claims: The Board is also distributing a total of fifty million (50,000,000) improved cocoa seedlings free of charge to farmers.

claims: I have requested Cocobod to unveil a programme to acquire land to engage more young people in cocoa farming.

speaker: H. E. John Dramani Mahama
claims: In 2014 a total of 319,000 direct and indirect jobs were created in tourism.

claims: Ghana suffers an infrastructural funding gap of about US$1.5 billion a year.

claims: The Ghana Infrastructure Investment Fund (GIIF) is financed by receipts from a VAT levy and contributions from tax, which has a funding mechanism already approved by Parliament, 2.5% of VAT receipts.

claims: Plans are being finalized to undertake the Kpong Water Supply Expansion Phase 2, Weija Water Supply Expansion, and the Asutsuare Water Supply Projects.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I conveyed my dismay at the full extent of the economic mess, in which our nation was mired.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We had inherited an economy that was in distress, choked by debt, and with macroeconomic fundamentals in disarray.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I am glad to be able to report that the Economic Management Team, under the stellar leadership of the strong, brilliant economist, Vice President Mahamudu Bawumia, has risen to the challenge, and the hard work is beginning to show positive results.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have reduced taxes, we are bringing down inflation and interest rates, economic growth is increasing, from the alarming 3.6% at December 2016, to 7.9% in our first year, and the indications are that it will be even better this year.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have increased our international reserves, maintained relative exchange rate stability, reduced the debt to GDP ratio and the rate of debt accumulation, we have paid almost half of arrears inherited, and, crucially, we are current on obligations to statutory funds.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I am also pleased to report that the 3-year IMF-supported Extended Credit Facility Programme, begun in 2015, comes to an end this year.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The relatively good macroeconomic performance in 2017 will strongly support our successful completion of the IMF programme.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We are determined to put in place measures to ensure irreversibility, and sustain macroeconomic stability, so that we will have no reason to seek again the assistance of that powerful global body.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have restored teacher and nursing training allowances.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have doubled the capitation grant, and, to confound the sceptics and professional naysayers, we have implemented Free Senior High School education.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: It has enabled 90,000 more students gain access to Senior High School education, in 2017, than in 2016.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have reduced the fiscal deficit from 9.3% to an estimated 5.6% of GDP.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Our economists have found imaginative ways to deal with the oppressive debt situation.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This has brought some relief, and the annual average rate of debt accumulation, which, in recent years, has been as high as 36%, has declined to 13.6%, as at September 2017.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: As a result, the public debt stock as a ratio of GDP is 68.3%, against the annual target of 71% for 2017, and end 2016 actual figure of 73.1%.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: As a result of appropriate policy, and the normalisation of the power situation in the country, they have also engineered a spectacular revival of Ghanaian industry, from a growth rate of -0.5% in 2016 to 17.7% in 2017.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: For the first time in a long while, our macroeconomic fundamentals are solid, and all the critical indices are pointing in the right direction.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We intend, also, to mine, at long last, our bauxite deposits in order to establish an integrated aluminium industry in Ghana.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Ghana Integrated Aluminium Development Corporation, a statutory corporation, has been set up, with the support of Parliament, to spearhead Government‚Äôs commitment to create an integrated aluminium industry.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The leadership of the corporation has been working tirelessly with transaction advisors and other stakeholders to ensure the objective of achieving an integrated aluminium industry is executed in a timely manner.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: A request for proposal is ready to be sent out to the market by the end of this month.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government is in the process of negotiating special arrangements to supply power at internationally competitive rates.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The same model is being pursued for the exploitation of our iron ore deposits, which, together with our considerable manganese deposits, can enable us to found a steel industry to serve our country and the region.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: A data centre, the first of its kind, now exists at the Minerals Commission, which will allow prospective investors and partners to access every information regarding the bauxite deposits and the aluminium industry.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Minerals Commission is in the course of creating an equivalent data centre for our iron ore deposits.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Ghana Armed Forces, in collaboration with other security agencies, have been in Operations CALM LIFE, COWLEG, HALT, CONQUERED, FIST, GONGON, CITADEL, AHODWO and VANGUARD.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Ghana Armed Forces assisted the National Security to embark on OPERATION ROADSTAR, and as a result a 40-cre cattle ranch has been constructed to accommodate over six thousand (6,000) cattle at Wawase, in Afram Plains, and reducing, considerably, the tensions in the area with the nomadic herdsmen.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government is pleased to have fulfilled its promise to the Military Personnel by increasing the United Nations Peacekeeping Troops contribution allowances from Thirty United State Dollars (USD 30.00) to Thirty-Five United State Dollars (USD 35.00) per soldier per day.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: MALOC was established in 2006 to meet a critical need by providing the type of small-scale loans needed by these small-scale enterprises at reasonable rates.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: MALOC was undermined by base political considerations and endemic corruption, and the centre was almost run down completely.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I am glad to report that MALOC has been revamped, and is getting back to do what it was set up to do.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: There has been strict adherence to credit procedures and prudent management of the credit recovery process.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: These have resulted in a recovery rate of 89% of loans administered under a pilot scheme introduced in 2017.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: MALOC was given an amount of thirty-five million Ghana cedis (GH¬¢35 million) in October 2018 for disbursement.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This is the first time an amount of such magnitude has been given to the Centre outside of an election year.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Of the thirty-five million Ghana cedis that were received, the Centre has disbursed twenty million, five hundred and sixty-three thousand, one hundred Ghana cedis (GH¬¢20,563,100).

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Fourteen million, three hundred and seventeen thousand, two hundredastest growing economy in the world.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I am convinced that the creation of new regions alone would not open up our country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have to improve upon the transportation system so that no part of this country feels cut off, or can be deemed to be too far from the centre.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Traffic jams and overcrowding are making our capital unattractive.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We are spending too much time stuck in traffic; it is unproductive, it is not healthy, and it is expensive.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have to build the roads to open up and link up the various parts of the country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Journey times between parts of the country have to be reduced.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: It is a shame that, some seven years or so after work had started on the Eastern Corridor roads, we are nowhere near completion.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This is a strategic road, that would provide a much shorter and cheaper link between the southern and northern parts of our country, and a suitable, alternative route for our land-locked neighbours.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: COCOBOD has issued directives to suspend work on all three sections of the road, which come up to almost 100 kilometres.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We are determined to find the needed resources to complete the Eastern Corridor roads.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: There is a crying need for work to be done on all our roads.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We are determined to bring our road network to a befitting status, and this year we shall witness much more activity on the roads.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We are turning our attention to private sector participation to raise the funds to do what needs to be done.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: With help from Japan, a loyal friend of Ghana, work is starting to build a three-tier interchange at the motorway roundabout.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The plans for expansion into a six-lane motorway will be implemented from this year.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: If we are to open up our country, we have to build a fast, safe and reliable railway network.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I am happy to report that we are making progress with the Takoradi to Paga railway.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We are in the final stages of agreeing with a significant investor the terms of a BOT Agreement, from Takoradi to Kumasi, which will be presented to Parliament this session.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: There is already a contractor on site for the construction of the Kojokrom to Manso section of the Takoradi to Kumasi rail line.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The process has commenced to select a suitable partner for the construction of the Eastern Line, from Accra to Tema to Kumasi.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The two countries are in earnest discussions as to the realization of the Ghana and Burkina Faso rail interconnectivity project.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: There are fortnightly meetings, either in Accra or Ouagadougou, and we are confident that deliberations will conclude, and actual construction will commence by the third quarter of this year.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have started the dream of a modern railway network in our country, which will become a reality during the tenure of this administration.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: A modern, reliable network of roads, railways, water transport and airports would transform our country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Fresh enthusiasm has entered the aviation sector, under the guidance of the dynamic Minister for Aviation, Cecilia Abena Dapaah, to link up all parts of the country by air.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The start of the digital address system, the introduction of paperless transactions at our ports, the rapid and continuing spread of broadband services are all helping to formalise and modernise our economy.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The framework agreement between Ghana and the Republic of Mauritius, for an initial investment in the development of a technology park in Dawa, in the Greater Accra Region, has been ratified by Parliament for implementation to begin.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We are working to strengthen cyber security to build confidence, and protect the use of electronic communications in national development, and ensure that our young technologically savvy people would keep Ghana firmly in the exciting IT economy and its many opportunities.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We need an educated and skilled workforce to be able to operate the modern economy we are creating.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We are reforming the schools' curricula to deal with the weaknesses in our education system, and lay greater emphasis on Science, Technology, Engineering, Mathematics (S.T.E.M), reading, history, and technical and vocational skills.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We are spending a lot of money on education, and I am certain that it is a worthwhile investment.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The reform of our schools' curricula should instill in our youth respect for the traditional values of discipline, fellow-feeling, hard work, honesty, integrity, and patriotism, without which no healthy social development can occur.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have cleared a substantial part of the debts and arrears that were choking the National Health Insurance Scheme.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This has led to the revival of the NHIS, and the renewal of respect for the NHIS card.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The health needs of our people are being better served.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We promised, last year, to increase the share of the District Assemblies Common Fund to Persons With Disabilities from 2 percent to 3 percent, and we delivered.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Effective July last year, the policy of ensuring that 50% of the persons who manage the country's toll booths are Persons With Disabilities started.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: There is a crying need for work to be done on all our roads.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Even with the ban, it has been a never-ending battle with the galamseyers, and I am sure the House will want to join me, in paying tribute to the members of our forces in Operation Vanguard that are protecting our environment.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have started various schemes to find sustainable alternative sources of income for the galamsayers.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The state of our rivers and forests remains a great cause for worry, and it is our sacred duty to protect them.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I am equally grateful to those chiefs, who have supported the fight against galamsey.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: A lot of hard work has gone into easing the intolerable debt situation that threatened to paralyse the energy industry.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We still have problems with the cost of power, and we are working to put Ghana at a competitive advantage.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We intend to find private sector operators to buy into the state-owned thermal plants, and inject the capital needed to bring power tariffs down for both domestic and commercial consumers.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The most reliable, and, ultimately, cheapest answer to our power needs, lies with renewable energy sources.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Already, the successful renegotiation of existing contracts has enabled us purchase, forthwith, 100 vehicles for the Police.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: In the medium to long-term, we will purchase drones and helicopters to assist the police combat violent and environmental crime.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The perennial problems associated with police accommodation will be tackled, and a compensation package introduced to cover officers in their line of duty.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We are rehabilitating the kraals or ranches that were abandoned after the Kufuor-led NPP government left office in 2009.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: They will become operational shortly to provide secure, grazing places for cattle.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We are determined to work to guarantee and secure the future of the young men and women of our country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The housing deficit is not limited to our security services, it is a nationwide problem that is caused mostly by the intolerable pressure on land prices.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government last year abolished the 5% VAT/NHIL on real estate sales.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The fight against galamsey is being spearheaded by a high-powered Inter-Ministerial Committee, led by the globally-acclaimed Ghanaian scientist, Prof. Kwabena Frimpong Boateng, Minister for Science, Technology, Environment and Innovation, supported by the indefatigable Minister for Lands and Natural Resources, John Peter Amewu.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have begun the difficult process of making housing affordable for Ghanaians.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Mr Speaker, the state of sanitation in our cities is wholly unacceptable.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government is working with various private sector operators to tackle this major challenge, with strategies that are intended to effect a change in our attitudes towards waste generation, as well as to improve dramatically our methods of waste management.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government will spend, this year, an amount of GH¬¢200 million to address the vexed issue of sanitation.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We are currently engaged in the very big exercise of creating new regions.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The existence of such a body would have forestalled the emergence of the Menzgold saga, and will make it difficult, in future, for any such scheme to get off the ground.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: A critical step, to this end, is the direct election of Metropolitan, Municipal and District Chief Executives on a partisan basis.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The constitutional impediment to this, in Article 55 of the Constitution, an entrenched clause, must, therefore, be removed.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: It was a ceremony that many had despaired we would ever see, but a new Yaa-Na, accepted by the two gates of Abudu and Andani, was installed on that day.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: It brought to an end decades of feuding that laid low the proud and ancient kingdom of Dagbon.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: It was a happy day, and it marked the climax of a long, tortuous journey, and a hard grind on the part of many people through the years.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I decided to summon all the resources of the state and my own energies, and make a concerted effort through the dedicated, patriotic Committee of Eminent Chiefs that had been working on the problem for the past 17 years, to find an acceptable solution.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: With the blessings of the Almighty, we have had a breakthrough, and this led to the month-long series of events that climaxed in the installation on 25th January, 2019.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I did want to do whatever I could to make sure that this long running sore, that was such a blight on Dagbon and Ghana, and which dragged down the development process in our country, could be resolved, and we could move on.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I wanted that amount of emotion, that time, that energy and that money to be spent on making Dagbon and Ghana prosperous.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I am grateful for the hard work and wisdom of the eminent chiefs, Otumfuo Osei Tutu II, Asantehene, the Nayiri, Naa Bohugu Abdulai Mahami Sheriga, Overlord of Mamprugu, and the Yagbonwura, Tuntumba Boresa Sulemana Jakpa, Overlord of the Gonja State.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Minister for Chieftaincy and Religious Affairs intends to use the momentum of the Dagbon settlement to tackle the other protracted chieftaincy disputes in the country, hopefully, for resolution.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I have decided that, this year, the official 62nd Independence Day celebration will be held in Tamale, on 6th March.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This will be the first time in our nation‚Äôs history that the celebration is being held outside of our national capital of Accra.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: It has taken 18 months of very hard work and some complicated manoeuvring to get to where we are today.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The first petition for the creation of Oti region, for example, dates back to 1954.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: It was time to deal with these outstanding issues so that we could get ahead with the business of developing our country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The creation of the six new regions opens up the country and ensures that no one feels cut off from the centre.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: It is for this reason that we have created the three development authorities.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: It is for this reason that we have re-aligned the national budget to ensure that every constituency gets the cedi equivalent of $1 million a year for priority projects.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I am able to state, and every member of this House should be able to testify, that work is going on in each of the 275 constituencies around the country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The water and toilet provision segment of the Special Development Initiatives is taking place in every constituency.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We came into office with a plan, Mr Speaker, and I am happy to say that we are working and delivering in accordance with that plan.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have the singular opportunity to avoid the old mistakes of urban planning that have made some of our towns and cities such unattractive places.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The political capital does not necessarily have to be the site of all the institutions, and this would guide us in the setting up of the new regions.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government is committed to the equitable distribution of government structures and institutions across the regions.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have also embarked on another aspect of our ambitious decentralisation programme, that is the exercise to expand full democracy to local government.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: In addition to the creation of thirty-eight (38) Municipal and District Assemblies, and the elevation of twenty-nine (29) Districts to the status of Municipalities, the Bill for the amendment of article 55(3) of the Constitution has been gazetted, to pave way for the direct, popular election, on partisan basis, of Metropolitan, Municipal and District Chief Executives (MMDCEs).

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: It is expected that a Referendum will be held on the Bill, alongside the Unit Assembly and District level elections in 2019.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I am calling, respectfully, for a repetition of the bi-partisan support, that made possible the hugely successful outcomes in the referenda for the new regions, to ensure the success of the impending referendum.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: A multidisciplinary panel of experts is being assembled to plan, cost, schedule and help implement a roadmap for the election of MMDCEs.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The economy is at the heart of all we seek to do, it is the success of the economy that will guarantee an improvement in the quality of the life of our people.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have just concluded a programme with the IMF, and, with continuing discipline, we shall sign off from the deal in April.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This is the seventeenth time Ghana has had to go to the IMF in the sixty-two years of her independence.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We cannot make the progress we all desire unless we are consistent and disciplined in the management of our economy.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The yo-yo nature of the boom and bust has not helped us achieve our goal of sustained prosperity, and lift us out of poverty.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have gone through another round of painful impositions to get to where we are today with healthy fundamentals.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Production in the economy, as measured by real GDP growth, has picked up very strongly in the last two years.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: From 3.4% in 2016, real GDP growth increased to 8.1% in 2017.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: In 2018, provisional data for the first three quarters indicate a strong real GDP growth of 6.0%, higher than the annual target of 5.6%.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Real GDP growth for 2019 is forecast at 7.6%.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Ghana‚Äôs recent GDP growth has placed it amongst the highest in the world.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The fiscal deficit is being brought down from the 7.3% of rebased GDP in 2016 to a provisional 3.9% of GDP at the end of 2018.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The debt-to-GDP ratio has declined from the 56.6% of GDP in 2016 to 54.8% at the end of 2018.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Inflation has dropped from 15.4%, at the end of 2016, to 9% in January this year, the lowest in six years, as announced by the Ghana Statistical Service last week.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have done this because we know the temptation to go on a spending binge will always be there, we know election years will come around and there will be pressure on government to splurge.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I am bent on running a responsible administration, mindful of the next generation, and not, merely, the next election.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Our efforts are bearing some fruits, and the world has taken notice of the improvement in our economic fundamentals.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: In September last year, after almost a decade, we received our first Sovereign Credit rating upgrade from Standard and Poor‚Äôs (S&P).

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This upgrade saw us move from B minus to B with a stable outlook.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: In December 2018, we also hosted the Managing Director of the International Monetary Fund, Christine Lagarde, a visit that was historical in every sense, as this was the first time that an IMF Managing Director had ever stepped foot on Ghanaian soil.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Revenue mobilization poses the biggest challenge in the management of our economy, with the tax exemption policy in particular proving to be an Achilles heel, and a growing menace to fiscal stability and revenue generation.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: In the last eight years, tax exemptions in respect of import duty, import VAT, import NHIL and domestic VAT have grown from three hundred and ninety-two million Ghana cedis (GH¬¢392 million), that is 0.6% of GDP in 2010, to GH¬¢4.66 billion, that is 1.6% of GDP in 2018.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: These figures do not include exemptions from the payment of corporate and individual income taxes, concessions on tax rates, petroleum tax reliefs, customs tax exemptions enjoyed by diplomatic missions, and waiver of processing charges at the ports.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: If we continue at this rate, in less than sixteen years, half of Ghana‚Äôs revenue base will be given away as tax exemptions.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This is not sustainable, and we intend to do something about it to reverse the trend, by introducing suitable measures that may disrupt the easy and comfortable arrangements that many have become accustomed to.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Workers in the public sector began the year on a good note, after receiving a 10% increase in their salaries, on top of the 11% increment of 2018.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Forty-one thousand (41,000) workers in the informal sector were also enrolled onto Tier-3 pensions schemes, with pensioners seeing an average increment of 11% in their monthly pension incomes, with the lowest income bracket receiving a 14.7% increment.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Last year, the Youth Employment Agency (YEA) engaged some one hundred and seven thousand (107,000) youth in various employment modules, with an additional one hundred and twenty-five thousand (125,000) set to be engaged this year.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government will shortly sign a landmark social partnership agreement with Organised Labour/the Trades Union Congress, the Ghana Employers‚Äô Association and Government, represented by the Ministries of Finance and Employment and Labour Relations, to provide a medium for building a sense of cohesion, trust, self-management, frank and open discussions to champion the course of development.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The fight against child labour has chalked some modest success.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Through the implementation of the second phase of the National Plan of Action (2017-2021), Ghana has been moved up from the Tier-2 Watch List position of the Trafficking in Persons (TIP) Report to Tier-2 in 2018.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government has introduced reforms at the port to improve efficiency.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We introduced the paperless operations at the ports and goods can be cleared within 1 to 3 days.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have set ourselves the goal of making our ports the most competitive in West Africa.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Ghana may be the toast of the world because of its economy.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: If they are uneducated or poorly educated, then prosperity will continue to elude them.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have no choice but to provide our young people with quality education and lifelong learning opportunities for every Ghanaian.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: It is the only way to ensure prosperity, and to protect our democracy.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We are not sparing any efforts to make education in Ghana of the best quality, and fit for the needs of the 21st century.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: In September 2019, a new standards-based curriculum will be rolled out from kindergarten to Class 6 in primary schools.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This curriculum has drawn upon the best practices from all over the world, and will focus on making Ghanaian children confident, innovative, creative-thinking, digitally-literate, well-rounded, patriotic citizens.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Mathematics, Science, Reading, Writing and Creativity are, therefore, at the heart of this new curriculum.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Poverty should not be an excuse for any Ghanaian child not to reach their full potential.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Education in the public sector is free from Kindergarten to Senior High School.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This year, legislation would be passed to redefine basic education to include Senior High School.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: All is set for the construction of 10 state-of-the-art Technical and Vocational Education Training (TVET) Centres this year.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The new TVET centres would be world class, and attractive to assure young people that they are not being sent to second best options.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Ten Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) centres are being built around the country to provide support for the introduction of STEM into basic education after the completion of a successful pilot phase.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Ghana‚Äôs young people will be able to acquire skills that would put them at par with their peers anywhere in the world.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I have appointed a Presidential Advisory Council on Science, Technology and Innovation (PACSTI) to advise the President on how to infuse the application of science and technology in the development of our nation.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: PACSTI is headed by a distinguished scientist, Prof. Edward Ayensu.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We shall bring before Parliament this year, a tertiary education policy Bill that will bring all the public universities under a common law, and make the administration of the public universities less cumbersome.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: A well-motivated and remunerated teacher is at the centre of our quality education and comprehensive teacher policy.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This has started with the upgrading of the initial teacher education certificate to degree status, and the move to put the teaching profession up there with other professions in terms of respect and exclusivity.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Currently, many of our teachers, who complete the three-year Diploma in Basic Education (DBE) at our Colleges of Education, go on, later, to do a two-year top-up first degree, by distance learning, at the University of Cape Coast.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: With the introduction of the 4-year Bachelor of Education degree, teacher trainees would now obtain their first degree at the end of their schooling.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: When our children master the connection between science and their everyday lives, we would reach the stage in Ghana where we would be rid of the many diseases, borne of filth and poor hygiene, that are still part of our lives.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We need to remind ourselves repeatedly that health is wealth, and it is only a healthy population that can make Ghana prosperous.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: In May 2018, Ghana won accolades at the World Health Assembly for having eradicated Trachoma, an eye disease that has plagued us for a long time.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Our NHIS is buoyant.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government has paid up the GH¬¢1.2 billion arrears we inherited, and brought the operations of the NHIS back to life.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: On 19th December, 2018, the introduction of mobile renewal of membership was launched.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: On average, seventy thousand (70,000) members are renewing their membership every week, by dialling *929# on any mobile phone network.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Soon, in collaboration with the National Identification Authority, Ghanaians would be able to register, renew and access health care services using the Ghana Card.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: In 2018, Government granted financial clearance for the recruitment of eleven thousand, one hundred and eighteen (11,018) health personnel to increase existing clinical staff.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: In September 2018, the Ministry of Health received further financial clearance to employ fourteen thousand, five hundred and twenty-four (14,254) Nurse Assistants (Clinical and Preventive).

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: These nurse assistants belong to the tranche that passed their exams in 2016 from Government Health Training Institutions, and have commenced work by 1st February, 2019.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The health delivery system will be significantly strengthened by the expected arrival in June of 275 ambulances, i.e. one per constituency, to make treatment of emergency cases more effective.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Drone technology has also been introduced into that system to help deliver essential medicine, blood and blood products to remote communities.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We still face problems of inadequate infrastructure in our health establishments.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have problems of numerous structures at various stages of completion that cannot be finished and brought into use, because newer structures are being started, and there is no money to finish the ones started earlier.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The 2019 budget made provision for the construction of two hundred thousand (200,000) housing units, and a database of local and foreign developers has been created to help make this policy a reality.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Land banks have also been secured in several towns across Ghana where factories, producing pre-fabricated building materials, can be sited for this huge construction effort.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Ministry of Finance is working to launch a one billion Ghana cedi housing fund that would target low-income earners.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government will continue with the other housing projects for the police, armed forces and government workers across the country, through agencies like the State Housing Corporation.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We are drafting plans to regenerate Nima, which holds the dubious title of being Accra‚Äôs first slum.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The regeneration plans will not dislodge or dispossess residents, but would rather transform Nima into a well-laid out residential area with full amenities.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: There is a serious problem of sea erosion along the coast that endangers the lives of our coastal people.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Odawna Storm Drains in Accra, which have caused many tragedies over the years, are now being reengineered by a team of experts who will give it a permanent fix.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Dichemso Drainage System is also on our list of priorities, and a bid has been put out for experts to transform it into a more efficient system.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Our ongoing coastal protection projects are proceeding in Adjoa in the Western Region, Blekusu, New Takoradi phase II (Elmina), Dansoman, Axim and Dixcove.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This year, we will also begin others in Amanful Kumah, Dansoman phase II, Komenda, Anomabo, Cape Coast, Mensah Guinea, Ningo Prampram, New Takoradi Phase III, Apam, Kokrobite, Bortianor, Blekusu Phase II and Aboadze-Shama Phase II, Maritime University, Nungua, Takoradi, Anyanui and Essipong.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We are putting in place plans to avert the perennial flooding caused by the spillage of the Bagre dam, which has resulted in the constant loss of lives and property over the years.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: In the short-term, desilting of the White Volta will be undertaken this year, in conjunction with discussions with the Burkinabes to regulate the flow of the spillage, and mitigate its impact.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Ministry of Works and Housing will, in the coming week, receive a report on a feasibility study conducted by the Chinese company, SinoHydro, for the construction of a dam at Pwalugu, to serve as a receptacle to hold the volume of water spilled from the Bagre Dam for irrigation purposes, and also for the generation of electricity.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This will be the permanent solution to the Bagre Dam problem.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have increased the share of the District Assemblies Common Fund to Persons with Disabilities from 2% to 3%.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have also ensured the implementation of our pledge of employing 50% of the persons who manage the country‚Äôs toll booths from amongst Persons with Disabilities.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We are continuing with initiatives to improve the Creative Arts Sector.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have also worked to finalise the Creative Arts Bill, leading to the setting up of the Creative Arts Fund.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: For the first time, in 2018, Government provided support to the Creative Arts Council.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Creative Arts Masterclass, to build capacity of Creative Arts practitioners, has also commenced.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Eastern Regional Theatre has been completed, and work is currently ongoing towards the construction of the Kumasi theatre.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have not been able to attract as many visitors to our country as we should.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We are making a special effort from now onwards to attract tourists into our country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Under the See Ghana, Eat Ghana, Wear Ghana and Feel Ghana campaign, the Ghana Tourism Authority recorded a 20% growth since its launch to over six hundred thousand visitations to various tourist sites.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The World Bank has approved a US$40 million grant to support the Tourism Ministry and its agencies to help upgrade tourist facilities.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: In September 2018, I proclaimed 2019 as the 'Year of Return', commemorating the 400th anniversary of the arrival of the first 20 West African slaves in the Commonwealth of Virginia.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We intend to use the symbolism of this 'Year of Return' to bring together Africans, persons of African descent, and all well-wishers and lovers of freedom to strengthen the commitment to ensuring that the blots on our history, i.e. the Transatlantic Slave Trade and slavery, never reoccur.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: In response to this proclamation, some seventy (70) African-American Hollywood celebrities visited Ghana in December 2018.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The year-long campaign, being coordinated by the Ghana Tourism Authority, is expected to increase arrivals considerably.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Training across the entire tourism sector is also receiving priority.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Hospitality Training Institute has been renovated, and re-opened in July 2018 to provide needed training in the hospitality and tourism sectors.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Under a Tourism Attractions Upgrade Project, several tourist sites are undergoing upgrades.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: A draft Legislative Instrument (LI) on Sites and Attractions is currently undergoing final stakeholder consultations.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This will ensure world-class standards are set and maintained at all our tourism sites and attractions.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The greatest attraction of our country is its people.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: It is the people of Ghana and our welcoming attitude that are the strongest attraction to visitors.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: In this 'Year of Return', I would urge each one of us to make a special effort to make a visit to our country a memorable one.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Our music, our foods, our clothes and the quintessential akwaaba smile will make a visitor to our country come back again and again.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Many of us do things that would put off any visitor from visiting our country, no matter how attractive the geography or the history might be.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Public resources must be channelled into ventures that generate wealth, and not spent on avoidable expenditures.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The cost of clearing and cleaning up our cities and towns after those who litter has become prohibitive.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The littering habit seems to be more predominant in the cities and urban areas, and, mercifully, largely absent in the villages.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I reiterated before you my pledge of improving sanitation in the country, and making Accra the cleanest city in Africa, by the end of my term.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: There has been a significant improvement in sanitation, even though, I acknowledge, more can be done.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have witnessed an increase in the coverage of solid waste management, from 16.6% to 53%.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Over the course of last year, thirty-five thousand, eight hundred and sixty-two (35,862) household toilets were built, as opposed to one thousand, six hundred and ninety-eight (1,698) in 2016.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We will intensify efforts at making Accra a clean city.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: In 2019, we intend to use the bye-laws to enforce cleanliness.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Ministry of Justice and the Ministry of Sanitation are working together to try sanitation offences.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Persons who litter would be tried and punished, and so would those who steal litter bins from our streets.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We are launching a National Sanitation Brigade to help us carry this out, and, through this vehicle, we will not only keep our towns and cities clean, but will also provide jobs for our young people.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Once waste is properly and efficiently managed, we then can explore how to use the waste collected to advance the economy of our nation.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: A cursory look around our cities and towns would show us that plastic filth is our biggest problem.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We intend to solve this problem through the internationally recognized priorities of waste: reduction first, followed by reuse, recycle, recovery and, lastly, disposal, which is to be avoided whenever possible.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government has prepared a Plastics Management Policy, with the overarching aim of meeting the challenges of comprehensive plastics management.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: About 82% of Ghana‚Äôs plastics waste could be readily recovered and recycled with existing technologies into value-addition products in high demand locally and within the West African region.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: A vibrant recycling industry in Ghana could recover nearly one million tonnes of waste plastics from the environment and landfills annually, to be recycled into basic-need products valued at GH¬¢2 billion per year, creating many jobs across the economy.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Currently, extensive discussions are being concluded with investors on the most sustainable options available to rid Ghana of this plastic filth menace.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We are also tackling the problem of electronic waste head on.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: On August 20, 2018, I launched the National E-waste Program to mark the commencement of two key provisions of the Hazardous and Electronic Waste Control and Management Act, Act 917.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Open defecation cannot be a characteristic of a country that is working to be transformed economically, and to be counted amongst the developed nations of the world.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: It is absolutely imperative that we make a success of our One House-One-Toilet Policy.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Community Led Total Sanitation (CLTS) Programme is being implemented in over four thousand, five hundred (4,500) communities in one hundred and thirty (130) districts to achieve Open Defecation Free (ODF) Communities.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Affordable and reliable energy is absolutely critical to realising our vision of economic transformation.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Gas production tripled during the year, from 100 to 300 million cubic feet per day.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Ministry of Energy is undertaking steps to remove the transmission bottlenecks to ensure that Ghanaian gas can reach power plants located in the eastern part of the country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I am confident that, by August this year, the situation would have been fully remedied to ensure Ghana uses locally produced gas for the bulk of its thermal power generation, saving substantial amounts of foreign exchange on imported fuels.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government is committed to achieving an electricity generation mix that ensures diversity and security of energy supply.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We will continue to promote the deployment of renewable energy in line with our policy target of 10% renewables in the energy mix from the current 1%.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: In spite of Ghana‚Äôs excess electricity generation capacity, we can still not achieve our universal access target because there are many Ghanaian communities, especially those on islands and lake sides, that cannot be reached through the national grid.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: There are currently two hundred (200) island and two thousand (2,000) lake side communities that require mini-grids from renewable sources to meet their energy needs.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Ministry of Energy initiated the Solar Rooftop Programme to reduce government‚Äôs expenditure on utilities and promote the use of solar power for government and public buildings.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Ministry is leading by example with the installation of a 65-kilowatt solar rooftop system at its premises.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Jubilee House will also be powered, as from August this year, by solar energy, as an example to other public institutions.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government‚Äôs target is to install up to 200 megawatts of distributed solar power by 2030 in both residential and non-residential facilities in order to reduce Government‚Äôs liabilities to ECG (PDS Ghana Ltd).

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Renewable energy has also become a necessary addition to our energy sector because it has increasingly become cheaper, and is key to the implementation of our international obligations under Sustainable Development Goal 7 and Sustainable Development Goal 13.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: There has been good news with the recent announcement by Aker Energy of one of the biggest oil finds in Africa.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This has led me to think that an NPP government must be good for Ghana.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: After many years of our looking and almost giving up, it took an NPP government to discover oil in 2007.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: In eight years of NDC administration, 13 oil block deals were signed, and not a single one was developed.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have established a National Register of Contracts on which all the Petroleum Agreements signed by the Government have been published.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This provides a platform for citizens to scrutinize the oil contracts signed by government, and accords with the international call for contract transparency.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have also passed the General Petroleum Regulations, which provide for the disclosure of beneficial ownership information of companies operating in Ghana‚Äôs oil and gas industry.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This will ensure that people do not hide in the shadows to appropriate oil blocks to themselves, at the expense of the citizens of Ghana.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The interest of major oil companies in Ghana has become dramatic.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Today, oil companies such as the American giant, ExxonMobil, and the Norwegian conglomerate, Aker, have signed petroleum exploration agreements with Ghana.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Through the launch of the 'GHANA OIL AND GAS LICENSING ROUNDS 2018', other global players such as BP, China National Offshore Oil Corporation, and Total have expressed interest in coming to Ghana.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have put in place the mechanisms to train young entrepreneurs and to help established businesses with a stimulus package to expand their companies.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Under the Presidential Support programme, one thousand, three hundred and fifty (1,350) start-ups and small businesses have benefitted from a special government business support programme.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Beneficiaries received between ten thousand (GH¬¢10,000) and one hundred thousand Ghana cedis (GH¬¢100,000) each, at a special interest rate of 10%, instead of the average prevailing market rate of 26%.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This is designed to help grow and expand their businesses, and will create about thirty thousand (30,000) direct jobs.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Eighteen thousand (18,000) jobs have already been created under this programme.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This is the first time in Ghana‚Äôs history that there has been a deliberate, systematic and coherent national support for start-ups and small businesses.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Businesses which benefitted included agribusiness and agro-processing, information communication and technology, tourism and recreation, sanitation and waste management, health, food and beverages, green and ecological businesses, sports and real estate.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Already established businesses are also receiving help, with an amount of two hundred and thirty million Ghana cedis (GH¬¢230 million) being disbursed among sixteen (16) companies under the stimulus package.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This has led to the creation of eight thousand, five hundred (8,500) to ten thousand (10,000) direct and indirect jobs.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Proof that we are generating the right atmosphere to attract foreign business has come with the announcement that three major international automobile manufacturers, Volkswagen, Nissan and Sinotruck have signed MOUs to establish assembling plants in our country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Renault is also conducting feasibility studies on establishing an assembly plant in Ghana, as is Toyota.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We will outdoor, in March, the National Automotive Policy spelling out the terms, conditions and incentive package for participating in Ghana‚Äôs new automobile industry, which will also apply to indigenous car assembly companies.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Our local textile industry has been struggling for years, and many textile companies have, indeed, gone under.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have decided to give it a major stimulus to help put it on a strong footing.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The local textile industry has, therefore, been granted a zero-rated VAT on the supply of locally-made textiles for a period of three years.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have put in place a tax stamp regime for both locally manufactured and imported textiles to address the challenge of pirated designs and logos in the textile trade.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Tema Port has been designated as a Single-Entry Corridor for the importation of textile prints, with a textile taskforce in place to ensure effective compliance, and reduce, if not eliminate, smuggling of imported textiles.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: A new textile import management system has been instituted to control imports of textiles.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The 'One-District-One-Factory' policy has taken off, and 79 factories under the scheme are at various stages of operation or construction.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Another 35 are going through credit appraisal.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Under the Rural Enterprises Programme, funded by the African Development Bank and the International Fund for Agricultural Development, 50 small-scale processing factories will be established by the end of the year in 50 districts across the country, particularly in areas where there is evidence of significant post-harvest losses.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: These will be owned and managed by organized youth groups, with technical support from the Ministry of Trade and Industry.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Small and medium scale enterprises form the base of businesses in our country, and financing has been the bane of their operations.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: MALOC was established in 2006 to meet a critical need by providing the type of small-scale loans needed by these small-scale enterprises at reasonable rates.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: MALOC was undermined by base political considerations and endemic corruption, and the centre was almost run down completely.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I am glad to report that MALOC has been revamped, and is getting back to do what it was set up to do.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: There has been strict adherence to credit procedures and prudent management of the credit recovery process.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: These have resulted in a recovery rate of 89% of loans administered under a pilot scheme introduced in 2017.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: MALOC was given an amount of thirty-five million Ghana cedis (GH¬¢35 million) in October 2018 for disbursement.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This is the first time an amount of such magnitude has been given to the Centre outside of an election year.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Of the thirty-five million Ghana cedis that were received, the Centre has disbursed twenty million, five hundred and sixty-three thousand, one hundred Ghana cedis (GH¬¢20,563,100).

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Fourteen million, three hundred and seventeen thousand, two hundred Ghana cedis (GH¬¢14,317,200) is to be disbursed for pending applications, which have been approved.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: So far, 87% of the monies disbursed have gone to women, i.e., to twenty-four thousand, five hundred and eighty-two (24,582) women.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The incidence of bad governance methods that almost collapsed MASLOC has, unfortunately, affected the running of many businesses generally and the financial sector in particular.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The banking sector has gone through what can only be described as a traumatic upheaval.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The woes of the banking sector have also been a case of long-standing bad practices that we, previously, had been unable or unwilling to deal with, which we are now having to deal with in the most painful manner.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The clean-up has cost the national treasury GH¬¢12.7 billion, money we can ill afford, but which was necessary to sanitise the sector, minimise job losses, and protect deposits of one million, one hundred and forty-seven thousand, three hundred and sixty-six (1,147,366) Ghanaians and their businesses and the people they employed.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The banking sector has emerged stronger from these developments, and inspired confidence in it.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I have been anxious that our local banks are helped and given as much support as possible, which has been done, but I will not be on the side of criminal behaviour if that is discovered.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I would urge that we are all patient for the investigations to be made in a calm manner.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This is a tragic phenomenon that appears to have occurred in plain sight and affected a lot of people, in spite of warnings from official institutions.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I admonish all Ghanaians to learn the necessary lessons for the future, even as State institutions work to bring a resolution to the matter, and those who are seen to have indulged in criminal activities are brought to justice.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I inaugurated the Presidential Financial Stability Advisory Council, an inter-institutional consultative coordination body, which groups together all the regulators of our financial system.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The existence of such a body would have forestalled the emergence of the Menzgold saga, and will make it difficult, in future, for any such scheme to get off the ground.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: During times like these of banking and business upheavals, agriculture appears even more attractive.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The past two years have shown that, when a government takes deliberate measures to support agriculture, it pays healthy dividends.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: There has been food and for the first time in a long while, we had more than we needed.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: It was not that long ago that Ghana was in the humiliating position of having to import maize from her landlocked Sahelian neighbours and plantain from Cote d‚ÄôIvoire.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Thanks to the programme for 'Planting for Food and Jobs', admirably organised by that outstanding Minister for Agriculture, Dr. Owusu Afriyie Akoto, this House stands informed that, in 2018, exports of food crops such as cassava, rice, yellow and white maize, soya, plantain, cowpea and yam were made from Ghana to Burkina Faso, Togo and Cote d‚ÄôIvoire in considerable quantities.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We had a bumper harvest of produce, and last year, we did not import a single grain of maize.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Based on the successes chalked in 2017 and then in 2018, the Ministry took giant strides to scale up the Planting for Food and Jobs Campaign in 2019, and to introduce new modules of the programme.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This year the Ministry of Fisheries and Aquaculture Development plans to implement a flagship programme - 'Aquaculture for Food and Jobs' (AFJ) ‚Äì complementary to the 'Planting for Food and Jobs' initiative ‚Äì to reinvigorate and boost the aquaculture industry.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Priority will be given to youth entrepreneurs, distressed farmers, second cycle and public institutions to set up and operate fish farms across the country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The programme will offer participating individuals and groups the requisite inputs, such as cages, fingerlings, fish feed and training, to be able to establish their own farms.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The AFJ will be implemented for three years, from 2019 to 2021, in collaboration with the Nation Builders Corps (NABCO) and the School Feeding Programme.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: It is expected to create seven thousand (7,000) jobs, and add an extra thirty-three thousand, six hundred and twenty-eight (33,628) metric tonnes of fish to our domestic fish production.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Piloting of the AFJ has already started at the James Camp Prison.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government will collaborate with the private sector to facilitate the provision of five thousand (5,000) outboard motors and fifty-five thousand, two hundred and fifty (55,250) bales of prescribed fishing gears through the fisheries associations.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We will continue to use the premix fuel tracking system, and audit landing beaches, measures which have ensured that, since November 2018, there has been no report of premix diversion, a marked improvement from the past.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: US$185 million of loan money has been earmarked for the construction of twelve (12) landing sites and two (2) fishing harbours in some selected fishing communities in the country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Phase I will kick off in March at Axim, Mumford, Winneba and Teshie.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I cut the sod to commence work at the Jamestown Harbour Complex, which is part of our plans for the fishing sector in 2019.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Our lands and water bodies have been under extreme pressure for some time.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Farming lands have been destroyed, and rivers that used to provide safe drinking water and fish turned into toxic water bodies.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This is why we placed the ban on all small-scale mining, so we could find ways to deal with the illegal mining, or galamsey, as it is popularly called.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The ban on small scale mining has now been lifted, but not on galamsey.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Some of our water bodies have shown remarkable signs of rejuvenation. River Ankobra, for example, looks restored to life; indeed, some fish have even been seen in the Ankobra for the first time in a long while.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: But the battle against galamsey is nowhere near being won yet, and I appeal to all citizens to be part of the battle to keep our lands and water bodies safe.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This government cannot be against mining. It bears repeating that, with the Almighty having blessed our land with so many precious minerals, mining, inevitably, will be part of our lives.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We intend, also, to mine, at long last, our bauxite deposits in order to establish an integrated aluminium industry in Ghana.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Ghana Integrated Aluminium Development Corporation, a statutory corporation, has been set up, with the support of Parliament, to spearhead Government‚Äôs commitment to create an integrated aluminium industry.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
