claims: Since its formation, the leadership of the corporation has been working tirelessly with transaction advisors and other stakeholders to ensure the objective of achieving an integrated aluminium industry is executed in a timely manner.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: A request for proposal is ready to be sent out to the market by the end of this month.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This request will solicit proposals from investors interested in partnering government to develop various components of the integrated aluminium industry in Ghana.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government is in the process of negotiating special arrangements to supply power at internationally competitive rates to the industry.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This arrangement is expected to be approved by Cabinet and, subsequently, hopefully, by Parliament soon.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The same model is being pursued for the exploitation of our iron ore deposits, which, together with our considerable manganese deposits, can enable us to found a steel industry to serve our country and the region.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: A data centre, the first of its kind, now exists at the Minerals Commission, which will allow prospective investors and partners to access every information regarding the bauxite deposits and the aluminium industry.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Minerals Commission is in the course of creating an equivalent data centre for our iron ore deposits.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The security services are at the forefront of keeping us and our nation safe.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I would like to mention the improvements that have been registered in dealing with nomadic herdsmen.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Ghana Armed Forces assisted the National Security to embark on OPERATION ROADSTAR, and as a result a 40-cre cattle ranch has been constructed to accommodate over six thousand (6,000) cattle at Wawase, in Afram Plains, and reducing, considerably, the tensions in the area with the nomadic herdsmen.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: There are plans to replicate these ranches in other parts of the country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government is pleased to have fulfilled its promise to the Military Personnel by increasing the United Nations Peacekeeping Troops contribution allowances from Thirty United State Dollars (USD 30.00) to Thirty-Five United State Dollars (USD 35.00) per soldier per day.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We will continue to pay the troops regularly at the operational areas.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We will continue to modernize and provide the equipment needed by the Military to help them carry out their mandate effectively.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I will be presenting to the Ghana Armed Forces 50 ANKAI Buses, the first tranche of the 138 Staff and Operational Vehicles of various categories, and 26 dispatch motorcycles.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This year, we will provide the Army with 30 Otokar Armored Personnel Carriers (APC), and 6 Fast Patrol Boats for the Navy.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We will also provide improved training facilities by transforming the Military Academy into a World Class Institution.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We will expand the housing project from six 16 flats to 44, and begin constructing 160 2-bedroom apartments across the country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We need this well-trained police service if we are to abide by the rule of law.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I am aware of the frustration of many at the delays in the justice delivery system, which are the result of a multiplicity of factors, which we are trying to address.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: It is obvious that most of the lower courts are not fit for purpose, and we must provide suitable structures for our law courts.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Discussions on how to raise the money are currently ongoing, and I am optimistic that a solution will be found.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I am pleased to note that there appears to have been a marked change in the Ministry of Justice.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: No longer do we have people bringing frivolous claims against the State because they know the case will not be defended, and they will get judgement debts.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I believe the word is now out that every claim against the government will be vigorously defended, and the State will no longer be the soft touch it used to be for people to get suspiciously large judgement debts awarded to them.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Parliament has virtually completed its deliberations on the Right To Information Bill, and that, any moment from now, the nation will hear the news of its long, anticipated passage.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I will, happily, assent to it as soon as it is brought to my table.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We all await the Special Prosecutor to start his work.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: It is in everybody‚Äôs interest that we know that any accusations of corruption in public office will be vigorously investigated and prosecuted, if the prima facie evidence is there.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This should be an essential feature of the governance culture of our country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I know the Special Prosecutor to be a responsible public official, who will act when he is ready.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Ghana remains an active player in international affairs, especially in the region of West Africa and on the continent of Africa.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Ghana‚Äôs voice is loud and clear on issues at international fora.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Good neighbourliness underpins our foreign policy and we try to be at peace with all.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I have been intimately involved in trying to find a resolution to the difficulties in Togo, and we hope that they are coming to an end.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Our roads, inside the country and those leading out to our neighbouring countries, have been in a dreadful state for a long time.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Everybody has by now heard about the arrangements we have made with the Chinese company, Sinohydro, and it is a matter of great relief to me that I am able to say that work will now be starting on the roads that have been designated to be part of that project.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We are very much aware that there are many more roads that do not come under the SinoHydro deal, which are also in a bad way and we continue to seek ways to build a road network worthy of our nation.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I am glad to be able to report that the Accra to Tema railway service has started running on the refurbished line.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: If we want the railways to work, we would all have to take an interest in and stop the activities of encroachers on the railway lands.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The rehabilitation of the narrow-gauge line will continue from Nsawam to Koforidua.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Work is continuing on the rehabilitation of the Kojokrom to Tarkwa section of the Western line, whilst work on the standard gauge section from Kojokrom to Manso is ongoing.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The government is committing an extra one billion US dollars to the development of the new railway network.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Five hundred million dollars ($500 million) will be applied to the development of the Western line, and five hundred million dollars ($500 million) will be applied to the first phase of the Kumasi to Paga section of the national network.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The development of the Tema/Ouagadougou railway line is also progressing steadily.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Twelve shortlisted companies have been invited to proceed to the next stage of the procurement process.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This year, land acquisition will commence beyond the Volta River at Mpakadan, and the strategic investor will be selected.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The railways are coming in a big way into Ghana, and we shall open up our country for the development that we all desire.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government recognizes the significance of aviation to our country‚Äôs economic and social development.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Operations at the Kumasi, Tamale, Takoradi airports have been revamped, with the resurgence in domestic airline operations through the introduction of new domestic operators like Unity Air and Passion Air.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Soon, the flag of Ghana will be flown again, as we have identified strategic investors to launch a Home-Based Carrier.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Mobile telephony has almost covered the entire country, and broadband internet connectivity is available in many places.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: There are one million, two hundred (1,200,000) registered and verified addresses through the National Digital Property Addressing System.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: People are able to renew their National Health Insurance cards in minutes in the comfort of their own homes.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: You can now renew your driving licence, and register a car in half an hour, register your business online, and acquire a passport in a week without any of the difficulties that used to come with trying to get any of these things done.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The National Identification card, the Ghana Card, has been issued to people in government departments and members of the security services, and this year, the rest of the population will be registered and receive their cards.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We are determined to join the digital world.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Ghana won, last year, the bid to host the 13th All Africa Games.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: It presents our nation with the opportunity to upgrade sporting infrastructure in the country, and position our nation as a preferred destination for the development of sporting disciplines on the continent.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have begun renovating and upgrading our sporting infrastructure such as the Accra and Cape Coast Sports Stadia, and the Azumah Nelson Sports Complex in Kaneshie, and a complete refurbishment of sports facilities across the country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: A member of this honourable House and the representative of Ayawaso West Wuogon constituency, died suddenly, throwing all of us into mourning.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: On 31st January, a by-election was called to elect a replacement for the late Emmanuel Kyeremanteng Agyarko.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: My first instinct was to let the police do their investigations, and then prosecute, if they found evidence of criminality.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The narration that this was another incident of 'normal by-election violence' caused me to expand my response.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Recent by-elections in Akwatia, Atiwa, Chereponi, Talensi and Amenfi West had been marked with violence, and some people still have their physical and emotional scars to show for it.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I decided that that would not be in the interest of Ghanaian democracy.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The time has come to put an end to the phenomenon of politically-related violence.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The only way in our system to begin to deal with such a situation is through the work of a Commission of Inquiry.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I got four responsible Ghanaians of independent spirit, who agreed to serve on the Commission.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I hope the findings and recommendations of the Emile Short Commission will enable us chart a path to ending politically-related violence in our country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The events of last Monday, in Kumasi, where a meeting of the national and regional executives of the opposition National Democratic Congress was broken up by acts of violence, leading to the tragic death of a citizen, have reinforced the urgent need for us to find that path.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I want to make a sincere, passionate appeal to the leaders of the two main political parties in our country, NPP and NDC, to come together, as soon as possible, preferably next week, to agree on appropriate measures to bring an end to this worrying and unacceptable phenomenon of vigilantism in our body politic.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I have asked the leadership of the NPP to extend an invitation to the leadership of the NDC for such a meeting.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The security services of the country will be on standby to assist this meeting.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: If voluntary disbandment by the parties is not feasible, then I will initiate legislation on the matter.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Mr. Speaker, I am glad to be here again in this august House to perform one of the most pleasant duties on the calendar of the President of the Republic, which is to give Honourable Members and the Ghanaian people a Message on the State of the Nation.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: It will be the fourth of my current mandate.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The House is aware that, since my last appearance here, we have a new Chief Justice in the person of Justice Anin Yeboah, who has succeeded Justice Sophia Abena Boafoa Akuffo.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: His appointment has been met with broad acceptance within the legal profession and the general population, testimony to his reputation for integrity and excellence in the conduct of his judicial duties.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I wish him Godspeed in the discharge of the functions of his great office and wish Justice Sophia Akuffo a well-deserved retirement after twenty-four (24) years in high judicial office.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I am sure we shall hear of her again in public service of some sort.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The House is equally aware that we have a new Inspector General of Police, Mr. James Oppong-Boanuh, an experienced police officer of thirty-one (31) years of service, who commands the respect of his fellow officers and the men and women of the police force and the public at large.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I am confident that, as he is already demonstrating, he will be in the frontline of an impartial, politically-color blind administration and enforcement of the laws of the country, especially in this sensitive election year.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I wish him a successful tenure of office and with his predecessor, Mr. David Asante Appeatu, well in his retirement.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Mr Speaker, some events in life leave an afterglow long after they have ended.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I believe we can confidently say that the designation of 2019 as the ‚ÄúYear of Return‚Äù, and the events that emanated from that decision have certainly left an afterglow that Ghana can and must cherish.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Ghana became the centre of attention in the African diaspora and, indeed, much of the world as we led the way with events of remembrance to commemorate 400 years since the first captured Africans arrived in the Americas in what became the beginning of the ignominious Trans-Atlantic Slave Trade.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The event, being commemorated, left deep scars and remains the source of unimaginable grief for all peoples of African descent; but it provided a great opportunity for us to demonstrate our triumph over adversity.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Throughout the year, and culminating in a glorious cacophony of celebrations, Ghana was the centre of attention in much of the world.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We played host to people from all over the world, young and old, men and women, black and white, joined in spectacular celebration, a joyous rediscovery of our common identity and humanity, exploring what we can do together, through political, cultural and economic engagement, to make our future brighter and better, one our future descendants will be proud of.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Mr Speaker, it is a matter of great pride to me that all Ghanaians embraced the Year of Return, and helped to project such a positive and endearing image of our country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: My heartfelt thanks to all Ghanaians and Members of the House, in particular, for the enthusiastic welcome that was extended to our visitors, and for making the Year of Return such a resounding success.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I cannot ignore the difficulties that currently exist in ECOWAS, especially with Nigeria, our age-old friend and largest member nation, closing its land borders for the past five months, and the instability and terrorist activity that is sadly blighting the lives of thousands in some parts of Nigeria, and shedding innocent blood in the Sahel and our neighbours to the north of our country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We are playing a positive role in the efforts being made within ECOWAS to bring this boundary impasse to an end, which will, hopefully, be sooner than later.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The successful implementation of the Accra Initiative, involving the consistent collaboration and co-operation of security and intelligence heads from Ghana and her neighbouring countries, namely Cote d‚ÄôIvoire, Burkina Faso, Togo, Benin, Mali and Niger, continues to be our concrete contribution to the fight against terrorism in our region.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Through joint security operations, such as KOUDANGOU and the ongoing Operation CONQUERED FIST, we continue to reinforce the security of our north-western, northern and north-eastern borders to guard against any infiltrations into the country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: All of us have a vested interest in helping to maintain the peace, stability and security of Ghana in the current, troubling circumstances of our Region.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We never lose sight of the fact that there are many Ghanaian communities in all parts of the world, and our missions abroad have been charged anew to be alive to their needs.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I am happy to report that Ghanaians in the diaspora are very much involved in whatever happens in their home country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Wherever I go, I meet with them, and they are often very well informed and insistent on accountability from government officials.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Let us never forget that the remittances from Ghanaians abroad constitute a healthy part of our economy, and I always encourage them to bring their acquired skills to invigorate the political and economic landscape.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: It is important that I make special mention of Ghana's relationship with the People's Republic of China, which has grown exponentially over the past few years.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The dramatic economic transformation of China in the past two decades is a marvel to the world and a lesson for the rest of us in the developing world.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have entered into various agreements with China, the lead one obviously being the SinoHydro agreement, which seeks to deliver many infrastructural projects.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Today, China is unfortunately battling an outbreak of the deadly Covid-19 virus.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We sympathize with the people of China at this time of great trouble.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I have written to President Xi Jinping to convey to the government and the people of China the solidarity and sympathy of the compassionate people of Ghana.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We trust that, with the tough decisions being implemented to curb the spread of the virus, this nightmare will be over, and, soon, they will recover from its devastating social and economic impact.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: There is a sizeable Ghanaian community in China and our government, through our Embassy, has been working with the Chinese authorities to find the best way to deal with the situation.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Ghanaian community includes four thousand, seven hundred and sixty (4,760) students, out of which three hundred (300) are studying in Hubei Province and two hundred (200) in the city of Wuhan, the epicentre of the outbreak.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We inherited a collapsing financial sector that has led to failing banks, and considerable agony to many people.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The government is having to conjure thirteen billion cedis (GH¬¢13 billion) to pay the 4.6 million affected customers of the banks.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This is money that we can ill-afford, and which would have gone to fund the many things that our communities are crying for.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Properly utilised, thirteen billion Ghana cedis would work wonders with our perennial infrastructure deficit.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: But, we did think long and hard about paying all the customers of the failed banks, and we believe we made the right decision.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I would like to repeat that all depositors of the savings and loans and microfinance institutions, including DKM which collapsed in 2015, will receive 100% of their deposits, too, once the validation exercise is concluded.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I am informed that the Receiver of the Savings and Loans and Microfinance institutions will begin, on Monday, 24th February, making payments to their customers, these monies, totaling five billion cedis, being in addition to the thirteen billion cedis being paid to the customers of the failed banks.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We hope that lessons have been learnt, and this will serve as a healthy caution to those who are offered unrealistic interest rates on deposits.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I do not think it will be possible to repeat this grand pay-up in another lifetime.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I want to assure Ghanaians that we are going to hold those who have been responsible for these failures of financial institutions (the supervisors and management of these institutions) accountable, a process which has already started.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We expect that those whose job it is to supervise the banks and other financial institutions will do their jobs honestly and competently.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I am very encouraged by the many corporate governance measures that have already been put in place by the Bank of Ghana, under the strong leadership of Governor Ernest Addison, to mitigate such bank failures in the future.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Thanks to the banking sector clean-up, today I am happy to say that Ghana's weak banking sector that we inherited is now well-capitalised, better managed, sound and liquid and the banks are now increasing their lending to the private sector to help propel the transformation of the economy Beyond Aid.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: A year ago, I started my speech here in Parliament with a reference to the happy events in Dagbon, and my presence at the enskinment of the new Ya-Naa Mahama Abukari II.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: About a month ago, the now-firmly in place Ya-Naa paid a historic visit to Jubilee House.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Ya-Naa and his entourage certainly shook up the place, and nobody would be forgetting that dramatic, colourful visit in a hurry.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Dagbon is gradually regaining her self-confidence, and I hope the House will join me in wishing that ancient kingdom the goodwill, patience and tolerance her elders, sons and daughters need to continue the healing process, and grow from strength to strength.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The peace, that currently prevails in Dagbon, is required for progress and development throughout the country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have spent a lot of money to ensure that the security agencies, that are charged with maintaining law and order and keeping us safe, are well resourced to enable them perform their duties.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We started with the banning of all small-scale mining, and, after about a year of the campaign, we made some progress as some rivers showed signs of coming back to life.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The University of Mines and Technology at Tarkwa took on the role of training local people in sustainable mining and by the time the ban on all small-scale mining was lifted last year, about four thousand (4,000) had received the training.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This Honourable House also did its part by amending the Mining Act to raise the penalties for illegal mining, and prohibiting foreign nationals from participating in any way in small-scale mining.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The nation is grateful for the intervention of Parliament.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The threat posed to the future of our country by galamsey is grave, and we cannot shirk our responsibilities in dealing with it.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I am appealing to the Media Coalition not be daunted by the difficulties in the fight against galamsey.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government will not weaken its stance, and welcomes the support of the Media Coalition.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Inter-Ministerial Committee Against Illegal Mining has been working hard, and has had some successes.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Under the auspices of this Committee, the Ministry of Local Government has formulated, and is implementing, the Alternative Livelihood Programme in thirty-five (35) severely affected 'galamsey' Districts across the country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Last year, five hundred (500) youth, mainly engaged in illegal mining, were trained and graduated in vocational and technical skills from Community Development Vocational and Technical Institutions.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: They have been provided with start-up tools and equipment.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: An additional six hundred and seven (607) youth are currently undergoing similar training, two hundred and forty (240) of whom are in the Community Development Institutions, whilst three hundred and sixty-seven (367) are attached to Master Craftsmen through apprenticeship at the community level.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Operation Vanguard has been largely successful, even though problems still remain.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Mining with impunity on water bodies and in forest reserves has declined.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: More than four thousand (4,000) miners have received training in sustainable mining.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The number of individuals, dying in collapsed mining tunnels and pits in the few unauthorized locations left, has reduced by more than ninety percent (90%).

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Operation Vanguard has been particularly effective in helping to restore the order which has permitted the reopening of the famous Obuasi mine of Anglogold Ashanti.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Community Mining Programme has been well received by the population, and young men and women, who did not have the resources to acquire concessions and excavators and other mining inputs, and, therefore, had to do 'galamsey', have moved into legal community mining.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Now, more than twenty-thousand (20,000) individuals are earning their incomes legitimately in the community mines in Akrofuom, Atwima Nwabiagya, Atwima Mponua, Adansi North, Amansie Central, Wassa Amenfi East and Wa East Districts.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Since the introduction of the Community Mining Programme, there have been no deaths due to the collapse of tunnels and pits.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Mr Speaker, another good example of deliberate, well-thought out policy, executed through hard work and commitment, that is generating dividends, is what we have done about food and agriculture in the past three (3) years.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: It bears repeating that agriculture was very much in the doldrums when we came into office, with a growth rate of 2.9%.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We introduced the programme for Planting for Food and Jobs, and set about to make agriculture an attractive profession.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We invested resources, expertise and time, and the results have been impressive and rewarding.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Growth rate in 2017 was 6.1%, and this increased to 6.4% last year.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Increased production and high yields of some foodstuffs like maize, rice, sorghum, groundnuts, soyabean, cowpea, cassava and plantain have led to a decrease in the wholesale prices in market centers in major food producing areas.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Furthermore, we are no longer importers of maize, we are reducing our dependence on rice imports, and are now, in effect, net exporters of foodstuffs.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Food prices are at their lowest in decades.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We recruited some two thousand, seven hundred (2,700) agricultural extension agents to give practical expertise on the farms.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We are not yet at the United Nations recommended ratio of one extension officer to five hundred (1:500) farmers, but we are working to get there, and it is definitely a vast improvement on the decimated department we met on the assumption of office.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: With the support of Canada, three hundred (300) vehicles and three thousand (3,000) motorbikes have been deployed around the country for ease of movement for those tasked to help the farmers.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Once the foodstuffs are produced, we do not leave it to chance and risk not being able to sell and, thereby, discourage the farmers.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The National Food and Buffer Stock Company (NAFCO) has been revitalised to enhance agricultural marketing, and improve access to market.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: NAFCO is promoting institutional procurement of produce and sales to schools and hospitals.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I am pleased to inform you that the Commodities Exchange in Ghana, which is fully operational, is promoting high productivity, price stability, increased exports, and reduced imports of commodities.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Trading operations, through an electronic trading platform, commenced in November 2018.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: To increase storage capacity, eighty (80) warehouses, each of a size of one thousand metric tonnes, are being built around the country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Thirty-five (35) have been completed by the Ministry of Special Development Initiatives, and thirteen (13) by the Ministry of Agriculture.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Ministry of Agriculture will complete the remaining seventeen (17) soon, and the Special Development Initiatives Ministry will complete another ten (10) by June.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Every part of the value chain is planned and accounted for.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The diversification of the scheme ensures that there would be something to interest a wide variety of people.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Planting for Export and Rural Development (PERD) module promotes the following tree crops: cashew, coffee, coconut, oil palm, mango, rubber and shea.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Parliament has contributed to the process of agricultural transformation by the establishment of the Tree Crop Development Authority, which is going to be responsible for husbanding the industries of these tree crops into full maturity, and expand by seven-fold our earnings from agriculture.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Rearing for Food and Jobs (RFJ) programme is developing a competitive and more efficient livestock industry that will increase domestic meat production and reduce importation of livestock.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Two hundred and sixty-five (265) small earth dams have been completed under the 1-Village-1-Dam initiative.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: At the heart of all these efforts is the determination to make agriculture an attractive business to young, educated Ghanaians, and this is why modernisation, mechanisation and the use of technology are all part of the scheme.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Digital and internet maps of soil fertility status in the Northern Savannah Ecological Zone are being made available to facilitate informed decision making on fertilizer formulation and application.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: An electronic platform has been established to capture and monitor the activities of participating farmers.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: As at December 2019, five hundred thousand (500,000) farmers had been biometrically registered.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Modernisation is finally coming to the fishing industry as well.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: New ways of doing things are being accepted and our fisherfolk are now ready to take a leap into scientific and sustainable methods of fishing.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: For two consecutive years now, our fisherfolk have accepted a close season, and allowed fishes to spawn without disturbance in our waters.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Constructions of the ten (10) long promised, much publicised landing sites, in Senya Beraku, Elmina, Moree, Mumford, Winneba, Gomoa Fetteh, Dixcove, Axim, Teshie and Keta, have finally started.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Axim, Dixcove, Senya Beraku and Gomoa Fetteh will be completed by the end of this year, with the remainder being completed early next year.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Construction of the Jamestown Harbour will commence in March, following the completion of technical work.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I am looking forward to the Business Resource Centres being built, helping the country to unearth some exciting, young entrepreneurs.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The young people that I met during the Presidential Pitch programme, for example, give me a lot of hope, and strike me as having the potential to benefit from the BRCs, the National Entrepreneurship and Innovations Plan, and take on the world.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The government is aggressively pursuing its plans for industrial transformation.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Whilst the Business Development Ministry works on bringing out entrepreneurial skills and encouraging young people to spot business opportunities, we are paying greater attention to making Ghana an easy place to do business and set up industries.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Having won the bid to host the Headquarters of the African Continental Free Trade Area (AfCFTA) in Accra, the Government has provided a permanent office building to host the Secretariat, and with the appointment of the Secretary-General in Addis Ababa two weeks ago, at the recent AU Summit, the office will become operational by the end of next month.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We extend our warm congratulations to the first Secretary-General, Wamkele Mene, the young South African, and assure him that we will give him our fullest co-operation to ensure he succeeds.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We launched the Ghana Automotive Development Policy in August last year, and it has so far attracted investments and commercial interests from some very big players, including Toyota, Volkswagen, Nissan, Renault, Hyundai, Sinotruk and Suzuki.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: VW is building its plant at the North Industrial Area in Accra, and is due to start production by the end of April.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Sinotruk has begun assembling its trucks.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Toyota is scheduled to start the assembly of vehicles in Tema in the last quarter of this year.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have high hopes for this new industry, which has come to join our own Kantanka.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We are determined, at long last, to exploit our large bauxite, manganese and iron ore deposits, which will enable us to establish an integrated bauxite and aluminium industry, and an iron and steel industry.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Ghana Integrated Bauxite and Aluminum Development Corporation and the Ghana Integrated Iron and Steel Corporation have been established by law as the vehicles for this exploitation.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The processes are underway for the selection, this year, of joint venture partners for the development of the full value chain of these two multi-billion-dollar industries, which will give a tremendous boost to Ghanaian industrialisation.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: All our best laid plans for industrialization would come to naught unless we have a reliable and reasonably priced energy source.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: It probably says something about the progress we have made that, in discussing the state of our nation, it takes a while even to get into our power supply matters.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: It gives me great pleasure to be able to say that we have overcome the DUMSOR menace.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I cannot say that we have resolved all our energy problems.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The five years of energy crisis led to the signing of what can only be described as usurious contracts that have landed our country with a huge financial burden.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The take or pay contracts resulted in the country being saddled with expensive excess power, and our having to pay nearly one billion United States dollars, in 2018 and 2019, for power we did not need.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: In the meantime, the industrialisation flagship project, 1-District-1-Factory, is progressing and beginning to show dividends.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: A total of one hundred and eighty-one (181) projects, spread across the one hundred and twelve (112) districts, are currently at various stages of implementation under the programme.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Fifty-eight (58) companies already in operation; twenty-six (26) projects currently under construction; fifty-eight (58) AfDB small-scale projects ready for sod cutting in the early part of this year; and twenty-six (26) pipeline projects are ready to commence implementation by the 1st quarter of this year.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: EXIM Bank, last month, signed a one hundred million United States dollar facility with Credit Suisse to help complete, this year, twenty (20) of the export-related factories.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: It is envisaged that the 1D1F initiative will generate a total of two hundred and twenty-eight thousand, eight hundred and sixty-six (228,866) direct and indirect jobs.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Even though the latest Ghana Living Standards Survey has recorded a drop in unemployment from 11.9% in 2015 to 7.3% in 2019, we still need to do more to create more jobs with urgency.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Struggling, existing businesses are also being revived and expanded under the 1D1F scheme.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: There is nothing contrary to the philosophy that underpins 1D1F if an already existing enterprise is helped to expand and employ more people.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: All our plans, all our hopes, all our expectations for a brighter tomorrow will only come to fruition if we can guarantee an educated and skilled workforce.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: A look at the national budget gives a clear indication of where our priority lies and it is with education.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Pre-Tertiary Education Bill, currently before Parliament, defines the priorities.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Basic education has been redefined to include Senior High School, and this covers vocational, agricultural and technical schools.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The emphasis is aggressively to promote Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics education across all levels of the education system.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I would like to add my voice to that of Parliament in encouraging the Unions to deepen their engagement with the Ministry of Education in order to find a consensus that will enable the Bill to go forward in peace.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: It was a Manifesto commitment to leverage technology to popularise the teaching and learning of Mathematics.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: It was with an eye to the future that we decided to demystify mathematics, and make Ghana a mathematics-friendly country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We need more engineering and technically minded people to be able to transform the economy.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Ghana's teachers are supportive of the many changes that are being introduced to make these hopes a reality.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The first cohort of Free SHS students are now getting ready to take their West African Senior Secondary Certificate Examination, and we look forward to them doing well.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Despite the continuing hostility of a few about the merits of the Free Senior High School policy, it has been widely accepted by the overwhelming majority of Ghanaians.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We still have some difficulties with infrastructure deficits, which are being vigourously addressed with the construction of nine hundred and sixty two (962) facilities

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government had to intervene in the administration of football, when we decided to dissolve the old GFA because of the bribery and corruption that engulfed its operation.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government worked with FIFA, established the Normalisation Committee, and helped bring a new GFA into being.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I am happy to note that football, the passion of the nation, has returned to full normalcy, following the election of a new President of the Ghana Football Association (GFA), Mr. Kurt Okraku.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Ghana Premier League has started, and let us help ‚ÄòBring Back the Love‚Äô.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This year we are going to conduct a national census, and it is incumbent on every citizen to co-operate with the Ghana Statistical Service to enable the Service produce an accurate census and date for our effective socio-economic planning.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We never lose sight of the fact that there are always some people who might not be able to run life's race at the same frenetic pace as the majority of people.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: It is the responsibility of government always to provide the safety net that would ensure that the poor and vulnerable are not excluded from the development agenda.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We will continue to improve and expand social protection interventions to cover those who need them.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: It is critical that the social protection interventions are targeted at those who genuinely need them, and who would use them to help lift themselves out of poverty.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Ghana National Household Registry (GNHR), in collaboration with the Ghana Statistical Service, is collecting data on all extremely poor households in the country through inter-institutional coordination, to ensure efficiency and effectiveness in social protection spending, and eliminate duplication in targeting and selection of beneficiaries for social protection programmes.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: For the first time in the country's history, a dedicated fund of five million cedis (GH¬¢5 million) to support women entrepreneurs with disability has been established.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The fund, known as Presidential Empowerment for Women Entrepreneurs with Disability, is to provide financial support to one thousand (1,000) women entrepreneurs with disability in two years, either to establish or scale-up their businesses.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Eight hundred and fifty (850) women entrepreneurs with disability across the country have benefitted from the fund, which is fifty percent (50%) grant and fifty percent (50%) loan without interest.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The support has enabled the women to expand their businesses, and to create one hundred and eighty (180) direct jobs and many more indirect jobs.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Presidential Empowerment for Women Entrepreneurs with Disability does not only help deliver a manifesto commitment, it is also in fulfilment of the SDG goals five (5), eight (8) and ten (10), which aim to ensure economic inclusion of women, and to harness their talents and capabilities for national development.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have begun the process of amending the Disability Act, Act 715, to comply with the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, and, hopefully, this House will pass it before the end of the year.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: As part of the Disability Inclusive Policy of Government, all Metropolitan, Municipal and District Assemblies have representations of Persons with Disabilities to enable them partake in local level governance.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Sixty-five thousand (65,000) new healthcare personnel, from 2017 to date, have been recruited.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The consultants of the project have submitted their final report, and the two Governments have begun the final stage of procurement for the strategic investor.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I am confident that, this year, the strategic investor will be chosen.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The preparation for construction has already commenced with the choice of the final route, and the acquisition of land, the right of way, will start immediately.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The contractors have assured the government that the Tema to Mpakadan line, which includes a three hundred (300) metre rail bridge over the Volta River, will be completed in August.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Those who travel along the Accra to Akosombo route would testify that this is a reality, as we can all see the work being done.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I hope to travel on that line in August.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We can safely say that the rail line journey to Paga has begun.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Work is going on to develop the railway network in other parts of the country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: There will be activity on the Eastern Line this year, and construction will commence on the Kumasi to Nyinahin via Aduadin rail line.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government is committed to developing suburban rail lines and inner-city light rail to ease the oppressive traffic situation within our cities.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: What is popularly referred to as the Western Line is receiving attention.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Kojokrom to Manso section, approximately twenty-two (22) kilometre section of the line, with a three hundred and fifty (350) metre viaduct, is being developed.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The contractor has been asked to develop a new standard gauge line within the Port of Takoradi, to convert the Takoradi to Kojokrom narrow gauge line into a standard gauge line, and also to continue the development of the new standard gauge line from Manso to Huni Valley.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Kumasi section of the Western Line will also receive attention this year.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government has decided to develop the Western Line from Takoradi towards Kumasi and from Kumasi towards Takoradi.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Development of the Kumasi to Aduabin section of the Western Line will commence this year.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This year, the year of Our Lord 2020, has been declared the Year of Roads.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This government is saying we are putting the emphasis on roads.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Gradually, the backlog of debts owed to contractors is being cleared, and many of them are able to go back to the jobs to finish them.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: A list of some critical roads has been drawn up and work has started on them.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Some of the names of the roads on this list have featured repeatedly in various speeches before this House in the past thirty years.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Some of them have even featured on lists of roads, that have been claimed to have been built, but that have turned out to have been artists' impressions.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Some of the roads on the list have, indeed, been said to have been built by so-called reputable contractors, but they have not survived two rainy seasons.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Once derelict State Enterprises have been revitalised.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: State Housing Company, Ghana Publishing Corporation, Ghana Post, GIHOC, State Transport Company, Ghana Maritime Authority have all been given a new lease of life, and are functioning with greater efficiency, and becoming again profit centres.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Digitisation has also led to a remarkable improvement in the delivery of public services.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We are all greatly relieved, for example, that the hassle has been removed for those who want to get passports.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We are equally relieved that DVLA offices are no longer the nightmare places they used to be, and we can get driver's licences without having to go through 'goro' boys.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I have not had the experience myself, yet, but I am assured that the STC has been transformed, and it is now a pleasant experience to travel on their buses.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: SSNIT has given a guarantee that when people apply for their pensions, they would get them within two weeks.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I am told most people get them within ten days, a far cry from the sad, disgraceful and humiliating experience that pensioners used to go through to get their pensions.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have implemented a digital property address system which gives an address to every location in Ghana.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We now have the first of its kind mobile money interoperability payment system in Africa.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The port operates a paperless clearance system; business registration is now online; we can now buy electricity units on our mobile phones; and e-justice system has been implemented at the courts.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This process of digitisation is also helping to curb corruption.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: For the first time in many years, Ghana has a fully functioning emergency response and ambulance system.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government has procured three hundred and seven (307) ambulances, with one assigned to each constituency.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Each ambulance has a tracker that determines its location instantly from the command centre.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The emergency number, one-one-two (112), has also been linked to the Ghanapost GPS system, such that if any call to the number is made using the Ghanapost GPS app, emergency services will know the exact location of the caller instantly.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We are employing drones to deliver emergency medical supplies in remote areas, and, today, Ghana has the largest medical drone delivery service in the world!

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Ghana is going to conduct, on 7th December, a general election, so that our people can choose the person and persons they want to manage the affairs of the nation on their behalf.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This will be the eighth (8th) general election of our history in the 4th Republic.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government, together with all stakeholders, is determined to ensure that it is peaceful and orderly, so that our people can make their choice in freedom and serenity, and exercise their civic duty of helping to elect a government of their choice on 7th December.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We should all commit ourselves to uphold the reputation of our nation as a beacon of democracy, and we expect the media to help lead the way in that regard.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: It is always an honour and a pleasure to be back here, where I was a three-time Member, to give a Message on the State of the Nation, as required by the Constitution.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Mr. Speaker, I hope you will forgive me if I begin by asking Members of the House to join me to salute the management, technical and playing teams of the Black Stars, who, against the odds, beat the Super Eagles of Nigeria in Abuja yesterday.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Their qualification for the World Cup in Qatar has brought so much joy to Ghanaians, and we are looking forward to an outstanding performance in Qatar.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Mr Speaker, from my vantage point as President of the Republic, from the focused point as head of government, from the enviable position of a husband, a father and a grandfather, I know that there is a general sense of anxiety in our nation at the moment.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Ghanaian people are anxious about the economy, the cost of living, income levels, jobs for young people, and even about issues on which we all thought we had achieved a national consensus.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: When some amongst us are raising questions about the certainties on which we are building the state, it is not surprising that worries about the stability of the government would become cause for heightened tension in the nation.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Mr Speaker, two years ago to the day, we were in the midst of a lockdown in the main metropolitan centres of our country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We were truly in the midst of the unknown.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: It took a while before it even got a name, but a pandemic it was, and the only certainty about it was that nobody knew very much about it.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The scientists, the health experts and the World Health Organisation were all united in their view that the virus would cause a lot of devastation.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The world before COVID now seems such a long time ago, and the trauma of a world ruled by a pandemic has changed all our perspectives.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Back in March 2020 when the first cases of COVID hit our country, we and the rest of the world were in unchartered territory, fear and sheer terror gripped our land.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Probably, to future generations, it will look quite obvious what should have been done, but, two years ago, it felt like we had fallen into a dark, malicious and terrifying abyss.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We could not have been prepared for the catastrophe that hit us, even the richest economies with the most sophisticated structures were unprepared.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Maybe some of us have forgotten what the experts were predicting at the time.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Our health and medical infrastructure was woefully inadequate, and we would not be able to cope.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: There were going to be piles of dead bodies strewn across the streets of Africa.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: There was a general consensus that we should spend all our energies and resources on protecting lives.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I remember, for example, the discussions about PPEs two (2) years ago; nobody was asking or was interested in how much they cost; just find them for our health workers and that was the only consideration.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I wonder how many people remember the cost of the first face shields and nose masks that came into our country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We provided nearly five million (5 million) households and over ten million (10 million) people with electricity and water subsidies at the time they were most needed.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: In all, data from the Ministry of Finance tells us that an amount of GH¬¢17.7 billion (or 4.6% of GDP) has been spent in containing the pandemic since 2020.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Mr Speaker, the NPP government came into office with a plan to build a resilient economy and set us on the path to prosperity.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We were on course, and our performance between 2017 and the beginning of 2020 demonstrates we were making rapid progress.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Indeed, in 2017, 2018 and 2019, we recorded average annual GDP growth rates of 7%, making us one of the fastest growing economies in the world.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We grew the economy from the cedi equivalent of fifty-four billion United States dollars ($54 billion) at the end of 2016 to the cedi equivalent of seventy-two billion dollars ($72 billion) in 2020, a thirty-three percent (33%) increase.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This is not something that anyone could have planned for, and the consequences are there for us all to see around the world.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The big and established economies of the world have been knocked off their planned trajectory.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Countries, where budget deficits were unknown and prohibited by law, suddenly had to accept huge deficits to underwrite social cohesion.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The economic devastation of COVID has, since the beginning of this year, been further aggravated by the Russian invasion of Ukraine, which has worsened the economic outlook of the entire world.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We, in Ghana, have not escaped this development, and the consequences are being felt in rising living costs at our markets and at fuel stations.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The terrible events in Ukraine have a direct impact on our lives here in Ghana.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Mr Speaker, thirty percent (30%) of our wheat flour and fertilizer imports come from Russia.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Sixty percent (60%) of iron rods and other metal sheets are imported from Ukraine, and almost twenty percent (20%) of Ghana‚Äôs manganese is shipped to Ukraine.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The bombs might be dropping on cities half a world away but they are hitting our pockets here in Ghana.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Even so, we have managed to ensure that fuel supplies have not been disrupted, unlike in several other parts of the world.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Last week, the Minister for Finance spelt out, in detail, to the country the economic and fiscal difficulties we face, and the raft of measures we are introducing to bring relief and restore us to economic growth.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The measures that have been announced by the Minister for Finance are meant to demonstrate that we are aware that we are in difficult times, and we are addressing the situation.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The belt-tightening measures being set for members of the Executive have been elaborated within this context.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This government remains alive to its responsibilities to the Ghanaian people.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The difficulties of the time notwithstanding, we intend to continue to grow this economy and bring prosperity.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The construction of eighty (80) warehouses, with a combined storage capacity of eighty-thousand metric tonnes, (80,000MT), has been completed, and their entry into the food production chain is offering better protection to the harvests of farmers.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: There is no doubt that but for the vigorous interventions we have made in agriculture in the past five years, which have made us more self-reliant in our food needs, our country would have been at much greater risk as the fallout from the dramatic worldwide increases in freight charges hit prices in our markets and on our supermarket shelves.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Mr Speaker, the cocoa industry has marked a lot of interesting and far-reaching achievements this past year, including producing one million, and forty-seven thousand, three hundred and eighty-five tonnes (1,047,385), the highest ever recorded in Ghana‚Äôs history.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Together with our counterparts in Cote d‚ÄôIvoire, we have addressed the inequalities in the international marketing system of cocoa by paying a Living Income Differential of four hundred United States dollars ($400) per tonne of cocoa to our farmers.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This is a remarkable initiative that cushions the income of the Ghanaian cocoa farmer, the backbone of our economy.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: A non-adjustable electronic weighing scale has been introduced for the purchase of cocoa from our cocoa farmers.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This scale, which was introduced at the start of the cocoa season in October, has been approved by the Ghana Standards Authority, it cannot be tampered with by purchasers.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The age-old belief/suspicion that cocoa farmers are being cheated by tampering with the weighing machines has come to an end.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The same use of technology to attract more young people into agriculture is continuing with the training of five hundred and thirty-seven (537) youth in the production of high value vegetables using Greenhouse technology.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: One hundred and ninety (190) of them have been on an 11-month internship in Israel, and they are back with a lot of enthusiasm.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We are expecting great things from them.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Indeed, Mr. Speaker, we are expecting greater things from the greater use of technology and the digitalization of our economy as a whole.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I am happy to report that the National Identification Card, the Ghana Card, has finally been integrated into our everyday lives as a cradle-to-grave necessity.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Never again will it be that someone, born in this country, will live a full life, die and be buried, without any record of his or her existence.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The operations of the Births and Deaths Registry are finally being digitised to make sure that documents issued from that department are accorded the respect they should have.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Every child born in this country will be registered, and the date of birth registered will remain your date of birth throughout your life.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: There will be no school age, no football age, no SSNIT age, and no official age.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: When we register for National Health Insurance, the details of our identification will be the same as the details on a driving licence, a passport and yes, on our tax identification.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Today, we all have addresses at which we can be identified, even if we live, unfortunately for the time being, in a kiosk.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Mr. Speaker, if we campaign so hard for the opening up of trading among African states, we had better have something to sell.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I am glad to report that despite the adverse effects of the COVID-19 Pandemic on firm-level production and productivity as well as the disruptions in global supply chains, the manufacturing subsector showed significant recovery last year.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Manufacturing recorded an average growth of 7.0% in the first half of 2021 compared to 0.7% in the corresponding period in 2020 at the beginning of the pandemic.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Our flagship One District One Factory (1D1F) Initiative is being implemented, with business promoters being empowered and supported either to establish new factories or to transform existing manufacturing enterprises to contribute significantly to job creation across the country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Mr. Speaker, through the 1D1F initiative, the made-in-Ghana label is being stamped on a wide range of products proudly manufactured in Ghana.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Out of a total of two hundred and seventy-eight (278) 1D1F projects at various stages of implementation in all the sixteen (16) regions, one hundred and six (106) factories are currently operational, one hundred and forty-eight (148) are under construction, while twenty-four (24) projects are at mobilization stage.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Mr. Speaker, in order to bring the youth on board the 1D1F Programme, fifty-eight (58) out of the two hundred and seventy-eight (278) 1D1F Projects have been developed as enterprises fully owned by youth groups, with direct Government support.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Each of these 1D1F Youth companies are owned by between forty (40) and fifty (50) youth as shareholders.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: In addition, five (5) medium scale state-of-the-art agro-processing Common-User Facilities (CUFs) have been established with direct support from Government and are owned by various groups of farmers, whose farming operations had previously been undermined through lack of processing facilities.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: These farmer-owned companies have been established in five (5) Districts, namely Dormaa West, Savelugu, Sefwi Akontonbra, Sekyere Central and Tarkwa Nsuaem.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: They cover oil palm processing, rice milling and the processing of maize into maize grits.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Mr. Speaker, quite a number of global vehicle manufacturing companies have set up assembly plants here in our country, and started producing vehicles for our market and for the West African market.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The well-defined Ghana Automotive Development Policy we outdoored in August 2019 has facilitated this welcome development.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Since June 2021, Toyota and Suzuki brands of vehicles are being produced here, commencing with the production of Hilux Pickup and Swift models.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: VW and Sinotruck, which commenced commercial operations in 2020, have continued to assemble their brands of vehicles and are enjoying significant local patronage.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: In addition, a new state-of-the-art assembly plant with capacity to assemble 5,000 new vehicles per annum has been established by Nissan in Tema, which is currently producing Nissan and Peugeot brands of vehicles for the Ghanaian and West African markets.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I will have the pleasure to commission this new plant in Tema tomorrow.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Three other vehicle manufacturers, namely KIA, Hyundai and Renault are also expected to commence commercial production this year.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The protection of our borders puts extra burden on the military, especially since there is increased terrorist activity in the Region and instability in many of our neighbouring countries.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Fifteen (15) Forward Operating Bases, or FOBs as they are called, are being constructed across the country to help in the prevention of cross border crimes and terrorist activity.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Mr. Speaker, I believe we can all testify that our Police Service is undergoing a great improvement and a change of image before our very eyes.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: During times of anxiety, we need a responsive police service to boost the confidence of the population and it is good to see the police rise up to the challenge.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Gradually, the police are bringing order to the roads and we all now know that the law is no respecter of persons or vehicle types.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I urge all of us to cooperate with the police to perform their duties to enable all of us go about our lives in peace.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I am happy to state that Government has been able to provide much needed modern equipment for the Service, and we are tackling their accommodation needs as well.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We are constructing three hundred and twenty (320) housing units at the National Police Training School, which are at an advanced stage of completion.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Work is also ongoing on the construction of a huge barracks complex at Kwabenya, to replace the one adjacent to the DVLA at 37, where the conditions of living are poor.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Mr. Speaker, together with the implementation of a number of operational and personnel welfare interventions, the morale of police officers has received a considerable boost, and, today, public-focused interventions, instituted by the IGP, have resulted in a better police-public relationship.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Police Service is gradually regaining the trust and confidence of the public, under the leadership of its new IGP.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Mr. Speaker, as I indicated last year would happen, a national dialogue on illegal mining was held under the auspices of the Lands and Natural Resources Ministry in Accra as well as two other regional ones in Kumasi and Tamale.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: If ever the support of all citizens was required to make something work, it is in the battle to end illegal mining, and restore our lands and water bodies to health.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have declared River Bodies and Forest Reserves as Red Zones for mining.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have suspended the issuance of all prospecting, exploration and/or reconnaissance licenses for minerals in forest reserves, launched Operation Halt II to help rid our water bodies and forest reserves of illegal miners, revamped the Community Mining Scheme as more sustainable and greener safeguards to replace illegal mining.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: What we need, above all, is the buy-in of all citizens to recognize that the degradation caused to the lands and water bodies by the illegal mining practices affect each one of us, and we should all take an interest to stop those involved.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Let me use this platform to extend, again, the condolences of the nation to the victims of the Appiatse Explosion.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The response to the disaster by the public and the organs of state was highly commendable.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government responded swiftly in the immediate aftermath of the incident by dispatching a high-powered delegation to Appiatse.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Mr Speaker, I cannot purport to speak about the state of the nation without addressing some critical governance issues that have featured in recent public discussions.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Certain elements have attempted to advocate coup d‚Äô√©tats as the answer to the problems of the nation.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
