claims: We came through a long and tortuous journey to arrive at today‚Äôs consensus on a multi-party democracy, but the last twenty-nine (29) years of our 4th Republic have shown that this has been the most productive period since our independence.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Both the major political parties of the country, the New Patriotic Party (NPP) and the National Democratic Congress (NDC), have made positive contributions to this development.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: There is work to be done on building our institutions, but our democracy is worth fighting for.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: It is up to us to find a way to accommodate each other and our differences to make things work for the benefit of the Ghanaian people.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Mr Speaker, it might also well be that coup d‚Äô√©tats have re-entered our discourse because of the turmoil in our neighbourhood.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The West African Region is suddenly back in the international headline news for all the wrong reasons; we are back again as the region of political instability and the place for coups.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Long and bitter experience led ECOWAS to its current stance of zero tolerance for military coups.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We, in Ghana, know the cost of instability; it leads to the exodus of our artisans and professionals, and the emptying of teachers from our schools.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Mr Speaker, today, at every traffic light junction in our big towns and cities, you can see the results of instability in our neighbourhood with the influx of refugees into our country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We should be unapologetic about campaigning for stable democratic Governments in our region.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We do not want to be an island of peace and stability in a region of turmoil.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We do not aspire to be prosperous in the midst of want and poverty.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We want a stable and prosperous Ghana in a stable and prosperous Region.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We should use our Chairmanship and membership of ECOWAS, our membership of the African Union, our membership of the Commonwealth, our membership of La Francophonie, and our position as a non-permanent member of the UN Security Council to advance these goals.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Mr. Speaker, taking into consideration the fact that COVID infection numbers have fallen dramatically, and on the advice of the COVID Taskforce, I announced, on Sunday, 27th March, in the 28th Update of the ‚ÄúFellow Ghanaians‚Äù series, the lifting of most of the restrictions that we have had to endure for the past two (2) years.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: As the health experts have advised, I hope we shall continue with some of the measures, like the washing of hands and the enhanced hygiene protocols, that have served us so well even though they are no longer mandatory.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I am sure we are all very relieved that the wearing of masks is no longer mandatory and we can hug our loved ones.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: With the lifting of the COVID restrictions, I am looking forward to renewed energy and enthusiasm, as all work places re-open at full capacity.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The qualification for the World Cup in Qatar has brought so much joy to Ghanaians, and we are looking forward to an outstanding performance in Qatar.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: There is a general sense of anxiety in our nation at the moment. The Ghanaian people are anxious about the economy, the cost of living, income levels, jobs for young people, and even about issues on which we all thought we had achieved a national consensus.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The trauma of a world ruled by a pandemic has changed all our perspectives.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Our health and medical infrastructure was woefully inadequate, and we would not be able to cope. There were going to be piles of dead bodies strewn across the streets of Africa.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I took the decision we would prioritize the saving of lives, and then we would get together to rebuild our economy.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Presidential Vaccine Manufacturing Committee... has put in place a comprehensive strategy for domestic vaccine production, and the establishment of a National Vaccine Institute.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We are undertaking the construction of 111 entities, which comprise standard 100-bed district hospitals for one hundred and one (101) districts without hospitals.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Agenda 111 is an ambitious project, which must and will be done, and which will create some thirty-three thousand, nine hundred (33,900) jobs for construction workers, and, on completion, some thirty-four thousand, three hundred (34,300) jobs for health workers.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: A great deal of the preparatory work has now been completed, and work has started at eighty-seven (87) of the one hundred and eleven (111) sites.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have saved lives and fared much better than we had feared and the experts predicted.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: An amount of GH¬¢17.7 billion (or 4.6% of GDP) has been spent in containing the pandemic since 2020.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The economic devastation of COVID has... been further aggravated by the Russian invasion of Ukraine, which has worsened the economic outlook of the entire world.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Thirty percent (30%) of our wheat flour and fertilizer imports come from Russia. Sixty percent (60%) of iron rods and other metal sheets are imported from Ukraine.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We intend to continue to grow this economy and bring prosperity. That will only happen when we continue to invest in the future.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Free SHS and Free TVET are the best vehicles we have devised to take us to the realization of our goal of an educated and skilled workforce.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This year, I will be commissioning some of the thirty-four (34) refurbished National Vocational and Technical Institutes (NVTI‚Äôs) across the country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government is in the process of securing financing for the construction of five (5) STEM universities in five (5) new Regions.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: There is great potential for our people in the creative arts, fashion, and film industry.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Creative Arts Senior High School, in Kwadaso, whose construction is currently seventy percent (70%) complete, will serve as a beacon for many young and talented people.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Ghana continues to lead the push for African renaissance through the decade-long ‚ÄòBeyond the Return Project‚Äô.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The ‚ÄúDecember in GH‚Äù component of this project has positioned Ghana as the destination to visit every December.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Last year, the country recorded some six hundred and twenty-three thousand, five hundred and twenty-three (623,523) visitors, up from the three hundred and fifty-five thousand, one hundred and eight (355,108) visitors, the year before.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government is undertaking a comprehensive renovation and modernization of tourist attractions across the country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The successes of the Programme for Planting for Food and Jobs have transformed the lives of many farmers around the country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I am glad to announce that the Tono Irrigation Dam has been fully rehabilitated, and is back to life and fully operational.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The rehabilitation of Tono, Kpong Left Bank and Kpong Irrigation Schemes has resulted in the availability of a total of thirteen thousand, one hundred and ninety (13,190) hectares of additional irrigable land.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Immediate benefits arising from the scheme include improved rice yields increasing from 4.5 tons per hectare to 5.5 tons per hectare.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This has benefitted some fourteen thousand, two hundred and sixty-four (14,264) smallholder beneficiaries directly, creating some forty thousand (40,000) jobs along several value chain activities generated from the irrigation schemes.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government has invested in the vegetable sector, through the Ghana Peri-urban Vegetable Value Chain Project.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The construction of eighty (80) warehouses... has been completed, and their entry into the food production chain is offering better protection to the harvests of farmers.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: But for the vigorous interventions we have made in agriculture in the past five years, our country would have been at much greater risk as the fallout from the dramatic worldwide increases in freight charges hit prices in our markets.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The cocoa industry has marked a lot of interesting and far-reaching achievements this past year, including producing one million, and forty-seven thousand, three hundred and eighty-five tonnes (1,047,385), the highest ever recorded in Ghana‚Äôs history.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have addressed the inequalities in the international marketing system of cocoa by paying a Living Income Differential of four hundred United States dollars ($400) per tonne of cocoa to our farmers.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: A non-adjustable electronic weighing scale has been introduced for the purchase of cocoa from our cocoa farmers.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The same use of technology to attract more young people into agriculture is continuing with the training of five hundred and thirty-seven (537) youth in the production of high value vegetables using Greenhouse technology.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The National Identification Card, the Ghana Card, has finally been integrated into our everyday lives as a cradle-to-grave necessity.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The operations of the Births and Deaths Registry are finally being digitised to make sure that documents issued from that department are accorded the respect they should have.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Rural Telephony Project... is important to extend basic telephone voice and data connectivity to every part of the country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Customs revenue... has increased by 27.6% to GH¬¢14.36 billion.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The digitisation of hospital records has started, through the Lightwave Health Information Management System.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The launch of PAPSS, the Pan-African Payment and Settlement System, simplifies the historical complexities and costs of making payments across African borders.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: 58 out of 278 1D1F Projects are fully owned by youth groups.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: 5 medium-scale agro-processing Common-User Facilities (CUFs) have been established.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Several global vehicle manufacturing companies have set up assembly plants in Ghana.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Toyota and Suzuki brands of vehicles are being produced in Ghana.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: A new state-of-the-art assembly plant has been established by Nissan in Tema.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: KIA, Hyundai, and Renault are expected to commence commercial production soon.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Kantanka brand has stepped up production of its made-in-Ghana vehicles.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: An embargo has been placed on the importation of 4√ó4 vehicles for official use.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: 100 courthouses and accompanying residences are being built.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: 121 residential units for the Judiciary are being built.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: A new Law House is being constructed.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The passage of certain laws has enhanced the capacity of the State in the fight against corruption.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Budgetary allocations for institutions engaged in public sector accountability have increased.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: A new Special Prosecutor has been appointed.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: More roads have been built, improved, and upgraded than in any previous period.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Tamale Interchange has been commissioned.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The government has kept the lights on despite worldwide upheavals in the energy sector.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: More Bulk Supply Points (BSPs) have been introduced.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The national electricity access rate has increased.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The first stage of the Military Housing Project, dubbed the Barracks Regeneration Project, has started with construction going on at all garrisons across the country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Military Academy at Teshie is being modernized, and we are keeping our Armed Forces retooled and equipped to enable them live up to their duties.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Each of the different branches of the Armed Forces ‚Äì the Army, Navy and Airforce ‚Äì has received significant financial assistance to upgrade its logistical bases, and strengthen its capabilities, and its welfare requirements are being substantially addressed.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We are building modernised Armed Forces, with higher numbers of personnel, that will be fit to meet the demands of the 21st century.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Our Police Service is undergoing a great improvement and a change of image before our very eyes.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Gradually, the police are bringing order to the roads and we all now know that the law is no respecter of persons or vehicle types.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government has been able to provide much needed modern equipment for the Service, and we are tackling their accommodation needs as well.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We are constructing three hundred and twenty (320) housing units at the National Police Training School, which are at an advanced stage of completion.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Work is also ongoing on the construction of a huge barracks complex at Kwabenya, to replace the one adjacent to the DVLA at 37, where the conditions of living are poor.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Police Service is gradually regaining the trust and confidence of the public, under the leadership of its new IGP.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have declared River Bodies and Forest Reserves as Red Zones for mining.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I am glad to be here in this august House to perform, once again, one of the most pleasant duties on the calendar of the President of the Republic, that is, to give Honourable Members and the Ghanaian people a Message on the State of the Nation, in fulfilment of article 67 of the Constitution.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The presence of women leaders, at both the local and national fronts, have advanced rights, enhanced equality, and, in general, improved the living standards and quality of lives of all concerned, including that of men.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Parliament stands as a symbol of our democracy and its values.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: It stands as a reminder to all of us that our country has chosen to travel on the path of democracy, and at the heart of that journey is the idea that the government can only govern with the consent of the people.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: After thirty years of democratic practice, we may be tempted to take it for granted.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The majority of our compatriots, who are in their early adulthood, have no personal recollection of the struggles that got us to this point in our development.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Only a small percentage of our population can recall life under colonial rule.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The memory of dictatorship, one party rule and military rule is receding into the dim past, and the struggles that have brought us so far are disappearing into the recesses of history.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Parliament directly represents the citizens of our nation in this hallowed chamber.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Democracy is not a static achievement, but a process that needs continuous nurturing.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: In our country's political history, it is the restoration of Parliament to its proper place that has always symbolised the restoration of power to the people.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: When constitutional rule is interrupted, it is Parliament that is shut down, the other arms of government continue to operate.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Thirty years ago, this House convened for the first time to mark the commencement of the Fourth Republic.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The early years of the return to democracy were fraught with challenges.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The years have seen the deepening of our democratic culture to a point where a candidate of the minority side in Parliament, today, presides as the Speaker.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Given the way the numbers shaped up in this House after the 2020 elections, many cynics and sceptics predicted a doomsday scenario for this Parliament.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Instead of a meltdown, we have witnessed considerable cooperation and unity of purpose among all parties and factions.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Today, we live in a country in which we enjoy complete freedom of expression, freedom of association, freedom of assembly, freedom of religion and political affiliation.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Freedom of speech has now reached such heights that even members of the diplomatic corps feel able to join in our national discourse, and pronounce on matters that would be problematic for Ghanaian diplomats in their countries of origin.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The important thing in our free speech environment is actually to try and hear each other, instead of raising the decibel level of our individual points of view.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: To come before this House to deliver a Message on the State of the Nation is a symbol and practical demonstration of accountability.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The issue, above all, that is, quite properly, dominating the concerns of all Ghanaians is the gravity of the economic situation of our country, and how we can quickly stabilise the economy, and work our way back to the period of rapid economic growth.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The COVID funds were not misused.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: It was Government that asked for the COVID funds to be audited, and nothing dishonourable was done with the COVID funds.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The responses from the Ministers for Health and Finance have sufficiently laid to rest the queries from the Auditor General‚Äôs report.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We provided five hundred and eighteen million cedis (GH¬¢518 million) of grants and loans to micro, small, and medium-scale enterprises (MSMEs).

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Three hundred and two thousand, five hundred and fifteen (302,515) enterprises benefitted from the funds, of which sixty percent (60%) were women-owned.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Fifty-eight thousand and forty-one (58,041) health workers were employed to supplement the existing health sector workforce.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: All of them have been absorbed as permanent workers in the health sector.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Frontline health workers were also granted fifty percent (50%) tax relief for the period.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: All households enjoyed free water supply and huge discounts on electricity bills.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The government took a deliberate decision to keep the inevitable disruptions in education down to a minimum.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We did not lose a single child to COVID in school.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have not been reckless in borrowing and spending.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have spent money on things that are urgent, like building roads, bridges, and schools.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This Government has built more roads than any government in the history of the 4th Republic.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have implemented successfully a National Identification System with the Ghanacard.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have constructed more railways than any other government in the Fourth Republic.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have established the Zongo Development Fund.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have constructed more infrastructure in the Zongo Communities than any other government in the Fourth Republic.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have constructed more NCA licensed fibre optic cable than any other government in the Fourth Republic.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The proportion of the population with access to toilet facilities has increased from 33% to 59%.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The number of public libraries has increased from 61 in 2017 to 115 in 2022.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have provided more equipment to security services than any other government in the Fourth Republic.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have successfully implemented the digital address system.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The One District, One Factory Initiative has 106 companies in operation and 148 factories under construction.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Ghana has the largest medical drone delivery service in the world.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have improved revenue collection through the introduction of an e-VAT and e-Invoicing System.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have reached a Staff Level Agreement with the IMF on a three billion dollar (US$3 billion) Extended Credit Facility.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The IMF Programme aims at restoring macroeconomic stability and debt sustainability.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Domestic Debt Exchange Programme aims to reduce the debt-to-GDP ratio from 103% in 2022 to 55% by 2028.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The participation rate of eighty-five percent (85%), representing tendered bonds of eighty-three billion cedis (GH¬¢83 billion) out of the total eligible bonds of ninety-seven point seven billion cedis (GH¬¢97,749,624,691), constitutes significant success for the DDE Programme.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The eighty-three billion cedis (GH¬¢83 billion) bonds that were successfully tendered, also, represents sixty-four percent (64%) of the outstanding domestic debt stock of one hundred and thirty billion cedis (GH¬¢130 billion) at the end of December 2022, as pension funds have been expressly exempted from the DDEP.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I want to take this opportunity to thank organised labour, pensioners, pension fund managers, the Ghana Association of Banks (GAB), Ghana Securities Industry Association (GSIA), Ghana Insurers Association (GIA), the Individual Bond Holders and Retirees Forum, and all others who have contributed to make the Domestic Debt Exchange Programme a success.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The voluntary nature of the DDE Programme bears repeating, as is the fact that the Government is committed to honouring all coupon payments and maturities in respect of both old bonds and the new bonds in line with Government fiscal commitments.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We are making progress on the external debt negotiations since the Government announced an external debt service suspension on 19th December 2022 for certain categories of external debt, to ensure an orderly restructuring.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The suspension is an interim emergency measure toward a comprehensive external debt operation which will contribute to the restoration of our debt sustainability in line with our request for a debt treatment under the G20 Common Framework.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I want to express our appreciation to the members of the Paris Club and to the Peoples‚Äô Republic of China for the co-operation they have so far exhibited to us in attempting to reach an agreement, and in their attempt to establish an Official Credit Committee.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We remain resolute in our vision to restore macroeconomic stability and promote inclusive growth.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government recognises that sustained growth must be deliberate, especially in a global landscape marked by forces of technology, trade, and intense competition.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Together with our private sector counterparts, we are anchoring Ghana‚Äôs medium-term growth drivers on competitiveness, integration, adaptation and digital innovation, all aimed at raising per capita GDP from the current two thousand, five hundred dollars (US$2,500) to four thousand, five hundred dollars (US$4,500) by 2030.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Concluding the arrangements with the Fund will not restore our fortunes overnight, but it will set us on the road to recovery.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: With fiscal discipline, we will regain the trust and confidence of our business partners and the investor community.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Gold Purchase Programme by the Bank of Ghana and the Gold for Oil Policy are creative uses of our resources, which are already bearing fruit.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: These policies are aimed at preserving foreign exchange, especially the US dollar, and stabilising the price of oil products such as petrol and diesel on the domestic market.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have already seen some success on both fronts with the price of US dollars and petroleum products falling since we announced the policy.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The average price of petrol at the pump, which had risen to twenty (20) cedis a litre, in the middle of December 2022, is now thirteen cedis and eighty pesewas (GH¬¢13.80) a litre.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The price of diesel had risen to more than twenty-three cedis and seventy pesewas (GH¬¢23.70) a litre and is now selling on the average at thirteen cedis and eighty pesewas (GH¬¢13.80) a litre, which is a reduction of almost ten cedis a litre.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We expect this trend of falling fuel prices to reflect soon in our daily lives, since transport fares affect the price of everything.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I hope the trend of prices going up and coming down become a regular feature of our retail economy as is being demonstrated in the fuel prices.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We dare not compromise on the safety and security of our nation, and my first responsibility as your Commander-In-Chief is to keep all of us safe.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The foundation for all development is the safety and security of our nation and its people.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The reality of the state of affairs in our neighbourhood demands that the government goes to great lengths to ensure the security, safety and stability of our nation.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The threats of terrorism and violent extremism surrounding us require that we pay maximum attention to protecting our borders.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This is the prime motive for the Accra Initiative, which is already yielding results.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Ghana‚Äôs total import bill was put at US$13.7 billion, according to GRA/ICUMS. On the evidence of existing local productive capacity, we have identified a list of twenty (20) priority products in the categories of primary agricultural products, processed foods, and manufactured goods, where we can confidently enhance domestic production. Amongst these are rice, fish, poultry, fruit juice, sugar, tomatoes, vegetable oils, oil palm, fertilizers, pharmaceuticals, soaps and detergents, insulated wire, ceramic products, corrugated paper and paper board, cement/clinker, and motor vehicles.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The report on the implementation modalities to enhance domestic productive capacity in these products has been prepared and, once confirmed, the new Minister for Trade & Industry will roll-out urgently a series of initiatives to implement the policy.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The YouStart programme seeks to support young entrepreneurs to gain access to capital, market, training and technical skills, compliance and quality assurance support and business development support services that will enable them start, build and grow their own businesses.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The YouStart programme was successfully piloted in 2022 with seventy (70) youth-led businesses benefiting from the initial GH¬¢1.98 million. Subsequently, a total of two hundred and eighty-eight thousand, eight hundred (288,800) applications have been received and are being processed by the Ghana Enterprise Agency for full operation.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government remains committed to infrastructure development. Working with the private sector, we continue to explore the use of Public-Private Partnership arrangements as a financing alternative to the delivery of critical public infrastructure, such as the Accra-Tema Motorway Extensions, Accra-Takoradi Motorway, and Sogakope-Lome Transboundary Water Supply Projects.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The seven hundred- and fifty-million-dollar ($750 million) AFRExim Bank facility, which has been secured, will make it possible for us to construct many other roads and interchanges, including the long-awaited four-tier Suame Interchange.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have now reached the point where we feel the impact of technology as an irreversible way of life. We have digitised many processes; the Ghana Card has become a one-stop shop for Ghanaian identity and its usages.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Our embrace of, and investment in information technology and the digital infrastructure will help us to redefine our traditional concepts of time, space, speed and nature of conducting business within our society, economy and culture.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have integrated many processes within the digital environment, and for this we have to recognise the efforts of many component parts of the government, such as the Ministry of Communications and Digitalisation, the National Identification Authority, and especially the Vice President, Dr. Alhaji Mahamudu Bawumia.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The National Health Insurance Authority has also improved its claims management processes with an emphasis on e-claims and paperless systems at all four Claims Processing Centres. In the year under review, electronic claims processing was about seventy percent (70%) of all claims submissions.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: As of 31st December 2022, the scheme paid a total claim of GH¬¢1.014 billion to health service providers.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Ghana now has six (6) centres for Zipline drone services, making Ghana the largest aerial logistics distribution network in the world. Zipline, through the national-scale drone delivery services, has delivered some 14.8 million (14,809,463) units of life-saving medicals, vaccines, and blood products to health facilities in Ghana by the end of 2022.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The current shortage of some childhood vaccines in the country has concerned me greatly. This shortage, if prolonged, will affect negatively Ghana‚Äôs Childhood Immunisation Programme, which has been recognised as one of the most successful in the world.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government has taken steps to ensure that stocks of these vaccines are procured and supplied, as a matter of emergency.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Ghana Health Service has developed an elaborate programme to catch up on children who have missed their vaccinations immediately stocks arrive.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This House has already passed into law the National Vaccine Institute Bill, which is yet to be brought for my assent.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government continues to prioritise agriculture as one of the driving forces for economic transformation. The experiences and lessons from the COVID-19 pandemic and the Russia-Ukraine conflict justify sufficiently our increased investment in the agricultural sector.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The agricultural sector recorded significant successes, with an average growth rate of 6.28% from 2017 to 2021.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have constructed some sixty-five (65) warehouses, with the remaining fifteen (15) at advanced stages of completion. This intervention is adding some eighty thousand metric tonnes (80,000mt) to national grain storage capacity.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: US$29.9 million worth of machinery and equipment have been procured from Brazil to boost mechanisation.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government will, this year, commence preparatory works for establishing a Tractor and Backhoe Loader Assembly Plant in the Ashanti Region, and continue capacity building of operators to ensure effective management and prolong the lifespan of agricultural machinery.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government‚Äôs response has been to continue to invest in irrigation infrastructure both large and small scales across the country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: In 2022, government completed the rehabilitation and modernisation of large-scale irrigation schemes at Tono, Kpong and Kpong Left Bank projects.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The three schemes are expected to provide six thousand, seven hundred and sixty-six hectares (6,766ha) of irrigable land for all-year-round crop production.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The National Electricity Access rate increased from 79.3% in 2016 to 88.54% in 2022, making us amongst the top six (6) in Africa, and we are still expecting to achieve the ninety percent (90%) universal electricity access rate by 2024.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Three (3) new substations have been commissioned between 2021 and 2022 thereby improving reliability and efficiency.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Since the last quarter of 2022, the Electricity Company of Ghana has embarked on an aggressive digital transformation programme.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: On 1st March 2023, all ECG District Offices became cashless. This is a major achievement by all standards. Since the start of this transformational programme, we have so far seen a twenty-five percent (25%) increase in the monthly revenues.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The second phase of the programme will see the digitisation of postpaid bills, and the digital tagging of all metres.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We continue the fight against galamsey with the support of the security agencies, in the short-term. However, we are determined to promote responsible small-scale mining through Community Mining Schemes.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: So far, sixteen (16) of these Schemes have been commissioned, with three (3) more to be commissioned by the end of this year.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Programme employs several youth in the production of seedlings and reclamation of degraded mined lands.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Currently, reclamation is ongoing over one thousand hectares (1,000ha) of degraded lands in Ashanti, Eastern and Western North Regions.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Ghana, as one of three Non-Permanent African Members, is working vigorously to push the Africa agenda, which includes the fight against terrorism, and the reform of the UN Security Council.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I am pleased to state that good progress is being made on the reform of the UN Security Council.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Biden, and the French President, Emmanuel Macron, have both embraced the Reform process. It is our hope that the leaders of the three other P5 Members of the Security Council will soon do the same, and help bring about this much needed reform that will bring greater effectiveness to the work of the United Nations and the Security Council in the maintenance of international peace and security.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We continue to be active members of the African Union and ECOWAS, and support strongly measures both bodies have taken against unconstitutional changes in government in our Region.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We are working with our partners in the Region to strengthen regional co-operation in the fight against the terrorist menace in West Africa, hence our commitment to the Accra Initiative.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Our decision to prioritise tourism, as a key policy for economic diversification, job creation and growth, is clearly paying off.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The World Economic Forum Report 2021 Travel Index ranks Ghana as the number one tourism destination in West Africa.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: International arrivals nearly trebled last year, from a low of three hundred and fifty-five thousand, one hundred and eight (355,108) in 2020, to over nine hundred and fifteen thousand (915,000).

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Domestic visits to tourist sites are also up by over 55.7% during the period.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: All these have been made possible by deliberate marketing initiatives and upgrades of tourist infrastructure by the Ministry of Tourism, Arts and Culture and its Agency, the Ghana Tourism Authority.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The ‚ÄúBeyond The Return‚Äù initiative, which I launched in 2019 as a sequel to the Year of Return, has re-ignited excitement about Ghana as the hub and a Mecca for the Global pan-African, a home every person of African descent must visit at least once in their lifetime.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I made the decision to rotate the Independence Day anniversary celebrations in order to enhance the cohesion and unity of our nation, and to make it clear to all segments of our population that we are all part of the ‚ÄúOne Ghana Project‚Äù.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Sixty-six (66) years since our independence, Ghana has taken steady strides to becoming a more developed country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Ghana of 1957 is not the Ghana of 2023. We have come a long way since the days of our six million population, with very few modern amenities for its people, to today‚Äôs population of thirty-two million, with a growing stock of modern infrastructure.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: As President, I have championed the innovation of policies and the execution of projects that have helped improve the quality of life of the Ghanaian people.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Our petrol stations have fuel, and we have been spared long, winding queues to fuel our vehicles.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Our markets and shops are, by the Grace of God, well-stocked, and we have not been faced with the prospect of the rationing of basic necessities such as fruits and vegetables.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Our children‚Äôs schooling has not been interrupted. We have continued to provide Free SHS, Free TVET and pay teacher and nursing training allowances.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Our electricity supply has been consistent, and we have been spared the hardship of Dumsor during such a trying time.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Our country continues to be stable and at peace.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Such moments call for strength of character, sense of purpose and an abiding commitment to the general good.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Let us believe in ourselves, and in our capacity to overcome the problems that are before us. This is a phase, and, with every fibre of my being, I am certain that this too shall pass.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: It is always exhilarating to be back in Parliament, and to discharge the duty, in fulfillment of Article 67 of the Constitution, of delivering to the House a Message on the State of the Nation on this occasion for the penultimate time.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: I am glad to be able to report that the entire territory that makes up our nation is safe, secure and under the control of the government and people of Ghana.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: West Africa is under threat of terrorism and violent extremism, rapidly spreading southwards from the Sahel to coastal West Africa.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Ghana, by the grace of the Almighty, is the only coastal state along the Gulf of Guinea that has so far not recorded a terrorist attack.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The peace and security we have in our country has not happened by chance. It has taken deliberate policy and planning on the part of Government.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have ensured a significant expansion of the Armed Forces and all the other security agencies.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The accommodation and physical environment generally of the security agencies are being improved.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have quickened the pace of the retooling and equipping of the security agencies to ensure readiness towards the emerging security threats.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Whilst we are spending money, time, energy and lives keeping the country safe from external dangers, I must add that it is a matter of great concern that we continue to have so many chieftaincy and land disputes around the country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: In its current state, Bawku is an alluring magnet to mischief makers and extremists operating a few kilometres across from the border.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government has, in the past year, undertaken a number of measures, including the establishment of a special Bawku Taskforce, and the intensification of engagements with the factions for the resolution of the chieftaincy dispute.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Four (4) radio stations, that have been broadcasting incendiary language and propagating hate speech, have been shut down by the National Communications Authority.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Chief Justice has also recently established specialised Courts in Accra and in Kumasi to deal expeditiously with criminal matters emanating from the Bawku conflict.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government is determined to do all it can to ensure there is security in every inch of the territory of our country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: There is, indeed, Mr Speaker, a state of palpable anxiety and tension in every corner of West Africa, raising the spectre of regional instability, which we thought had been banished.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Unconstitutional changes in Government in parts of Africa, especially in West Africa, through a series of coup d‚Äô√©tats and military interventions in governance, testify to an unfortunate democratic regression in the Region.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We, in Ghana, continue to give maximum support to ECOWAS, the regional body of West Africa, and the African Union, Africa‚Äôs continental organisation, in their efforts to restore democratic institutions in the affected nations.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We believe also that a reform of the global governance architecture, such as the Security Council of the United Nations, to make it more representative and accountable, will help strengthen global peace and stability, and, thereby, help consolidate democratic rule in the world.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: It might sound new to some, but those of us who have been around for a while have heard the argument made passionately that democracy was not a suitable form of Government if we wanted rapid development.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: There are also those amongst us who consider the rough and tumble of politics to be beneath them, and would not want their sainted images to be soiled by what they term the dirt of politics.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Nobody should undermine the integrity of the arms of government for parochial reasons.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: There is definitely much room for improvement in the workings of the Executive arm of Government, the Judiciary and our Parliament.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Even those who have had Parliaments as part of their governance systems for hundreds of years still make mistakes, and, sometimes, get things alarmingly wrong.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: It would be surprising if our thirty-one (31) year old Parliament did not get things wrong sometimes.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: This august House, which holds so many fond memories for me of my personal political journey, does not always measure up to the expectations of the people or, even sometimes, of its own members.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: There is a lot of anxiety currently about how our MPs get elected, there is anxiety about the rapid turnover of Members in the House, and the loss of institutional memory.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We would not all agree with everything that Parliament does and, I daresay, Mr Speaker, that I do not agree with everything that goes on in here, but that is the beauty of what we, as a people, are trying to do in our governance structure.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The president and his appointees are not universally loved, and it will be strange and unproductive if they were.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Under the Constitution, the executive power of the state is vested in the President of the Republic. He or she is the Executive.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: There is no ambiguity about where the buck stops, when it comes to responsibility for what happens in the government. It stops with the President.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The President holds the executive power.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Ultimately, the President is responsible, and, therefore, takes the credit or the blame for whatever happens in his or her government.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The programmes that come from the Executive benefit from the rigorous public examination and debates to which they are subjected.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We all now take for granted and, sometimes, even bemoan the vigorous media and civil society organisation scrutiny that characterise public discourse.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: It gives me quiet satisfaction and great pride to hear young Ghanaians, today, who believe that criticising the President of the Republic and challenging government proposals are normal, regular activities.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Some of the young people listen with incredulity when they hear about a Ghana that was once without private radio stations, and people had to tune in to foreign stations to hear critical and opposition voices.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Today, there are some five hundred and fifty (550) radio stations in operation in the country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: In spite of all its shortcomings and difficulties, the people of Ghana have shown admirable commitment to multi-party democracy, and have not fallen for the instigations to resort to the violent overthrow of an elected government.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The past thirty-two (32) years of the Fourth Republic have witnessed the most sustained period of stability and economic growth in our country.

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: the implementation of various programmes such as Capitation Grant, Feeding Grants to Special Schools, BECE registration for pupils in public Junior High Schools, amongst others, have significantly increased access to education at the basic level

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: A National Standardized Test for numeracy and reading skills is now being conducted at primary four (4)

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: seventeen thousand, three hundred and forty (17,340) out-of-school children have been taken through the programme and mainstreamed into formal schools in 2023

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: These schools have been equipped with state-of-the-art laboratories and classrooms, dormitories, assembly halls, dining halls and conducive environments to foster teaching and learning

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: my government was determined that DUMSOR would not be inflicted upon Ghana and Ghanaians under an NPP government, and I am glad to be able to say, SO FAR, SO GOOD, we have managed to keep the lights on these last seven (7) years

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We have managed the energy sector with discipline and expertise, to avoid a repetition of the hardships inflicted on Ghanaians some years ago

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government has directly intervened to stimulate interest in, and support many private sector business promoters to make significant investments in manufacturing under the One-District-One-Factory Programme

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: this has led to the development of three hundred and twenty-one (321) 1D1F projects, consisting of two hundred and eleven (211) new, medium to large scale factories, and the conscious enabling of one hundred and ten (110) existing companies, to inject significant capital investments into the expansion of production facilities, and diversification of products

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: these business promoters have so far invested in one hundred and forty-two (142) districts across the country, across all sixteen (16) regions, and achieving fifty-four percent (54%) district coverage

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: within this period, some one hundred and seventy thousand (170,000) jobs have been created under the novel 1D1F Programme by companies in operation

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: the comprehensive Automotive Development Policy, launched by Government in August, 2019, has undoubtedly been the catalyst that has attracted a record number of twelve (12) Original Equipment Manufacturers, including Volkswagen, Toyota, Suzuki, Nissan, Peugeot, KIA, Hyundai, Honda to set up assembly plants, and produce a range of models here in Ghana

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Toyota Ghana has partnered the School of Engineering Sciences of the University of Ghana to establish and operate a modern Auto Engineering Training Centre for engineering students and the industry to acquire applied auto engineering training

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: KIA Motor Company of Korea has upgraded the Rana Motors West African Vehicle Academy (WAVA), with state-of-the-art equipment for training of auto repair and maintenance technicians, including repair and maintenance of Electric Vehicles

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: we are implementing the Four Project Agenda of the Ghana Integrated Aluminium Development Corporation (GIADEC), with Projects 1 and 2 having, already, taken off, and last month, we signed an agreement for the implementation of Project 3

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: We will lay before this august House, at this First Meeting of this Session of Parliament, a Legislative Instrument to prohibit the export of bauxite in its raw state

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: we are, also, in the concluding phase of discussions for the establishment of a four hundred and fifty million US dollar (US$450 million) refinery to refine the manganese we produce

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Ghana is one of the seven (7) countries selected to participate in the Guided Trade Initiative (GTI) of the AfCFTA Secretariat, and this has enabled us to make significant inroads into East Africa, notably Kenya and Tanzania

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: over seven hundred (700) AfCFTA certified products from Ghana, like cosmetics, processed foods, beverages, coconut oil, shea butter and garments have been targeted at the AfCFTA market under the Guided Trade Initiative

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Kasapreko Company Limited, one of our iconic local beverage manufacturers, which has commenced exports to the Kenyan market

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: many other Ghanaian companies now have set their horizons way beyond the shores of our country, and see the entire African continent as the market to aim at

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: formal sector employees form only a small part of the working population

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: since the launch of the SEED initiative, some six hundred thousand (600,000) self-employed persons have been enrolled onto the programme, and now have some form of social security cover

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: effective 1st January 2024, all pensioners on the SSNIT Pension Payroll as of 31st December 2023, have had their monthly pensions increased by fifteen percent (15%)

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: this translates to ten-point-zero-five percent (10.05%) effective increase for the highest-earning pensioners, and thirty-six-point-three-seven percent (36.37%) effective increase for the lowest-earning pensioners

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: the fifteen percent (15%) indexation rate will result in an additional expenditure of six hundred and ninety-seven million cedis (GH¬¢697.64 million)

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: the total benefit expenditure for Government, under the SSNIT Scheme alone, is projected to increase from five-point-four billion cedis (GH¬¢5.446 billion) in 2023 to seven billion cedis (GH¬¢7.034 billion) in 2024

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Ghana is finally realising her long-promised potential in the tourism sector

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: visitor numbers in the tourism sector have been increasing every year

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: decriminal in GH‚Äù is now an established and increasingly attractive phenomenon, which brings visitors to our country in the month of December, and has changed the events calendar around the Christmas holiday season in Accra and many other towns

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government has undertaken a full modernisation rehabilitation of the Kwame Nkrumah Memorial Park

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: since the commissioning of the modernised park in July 2023, the number of domestic and international visitors has risen dramatically

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: there have been two hundred and eight thousand, five hundred and fifty-seven (208,557) domestic and international visitors to the Park between 14th July and 31st December 2023

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: the National Museum Gallery, which had been closed down since 2015, has also been fully refurbished

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: it attracted over thirty-five thousand (35,000) visitors in 2023

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: school children form a good part of the visitors to these sites

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: the first-ever Kente Museum, aimed at preserving the cultural heritage in Ghana, has been built at Bonwire in the Ashanti Region, and was recently commissioned by the Second Lady

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: preparatory works and designs for the construction of the Heroes Park, a museum to commemorate the founding fathers of Ghana, the Big Six, were completed in December 2023, and construction will commence very soon

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government, through the National Film Authority, is committed to supporting the production of world class content and films, as well as increasing the cinema infrastructure in Ghana and, by extension, on the continent

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: a favourable fiscal (tax) regime for cinema projects, including income tax and VAT incentives, import duty exemptions on film production equipment, twenty percent (20%) tax rebate for strategic film productions and film financing reliefs, is being elaborated by Cabinet

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: the revised National Gender Policy and the Affirmative Action Bill were approved by Cabinet in October 2023

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: the Affirmative Action Bill is currently before Parliament for consideration and approval

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The Ghana Enterprises Agency (GEA) is implementing an only women support programme, where micro, small and medium enterprises, owned by women, with the potential for scaling up their operations, increasing sales and creating sustainable jobs, will receive liquidity support

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: The GEA is also implementing the YouStart Programme, a youth empowerment programme, which recently disbursed one hundred million cedis (GH¬¢100 million) to some three thousand youth beneficiaries to upscale their businesses

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Government launched the twelve-million-cedi (GH¬¢12 million) PWD Enterprise Support Programme, a grant support programme, under the Ghana Transformative Project, which is being funded by the World Bank

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: the Youth Employment Agency has initiated a ground breaking employment drive targeting two hundred and eighty-two (282) persons with disabilities who worked at tollbooths

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Ghana regained her position as the leading producer of gold in Africa, having overtaken South Africa

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: our gold production reached an unprecedented four million ounces (4 million oz), according to preliminary reports

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: the reduction in withholding tax on unprocessed gold by small scale miners, from three percent (3%) to one and a half percent (1.5%), has resulted in some nine hundred percent (900%) increment in gold export from the small-scale sector, over the last two (2) years

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: we introduced the innovative Gold for Oil Policy, which accounts for some thirty percent (30%) of our total crude oil consumption

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: three (3) large scale mines are under construction in Ahafo, Upper East and Upper West Regions, with Cardinal Namdini set to pour its first gold in the Upper East Region in the last quarter of this year

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: with these new mines, our gold production is expected to increase to some four point five million ounces (4.5 million oz) annually

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: we have constructed, through a public private partnership, a four hundred kilogramme (400kg) capacity gold refinery, and we are in the final stages of negotiations for a London Bullion Market Association (LBMA) Certificate

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: for our green minerals, including lithium, we have put in place a policy for their exploitation and management, to ensure beneficiation across the value chain of these critical minerals

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: Newmont Corporation, the world‚Äôs largest gold producing company, which operates two huge mines in our country, and is constructing a third, has announced its intention to sell its Akyem Mine in the Eastern Region, the third largest mine in the country, which produced some four hundred and twenty thousand (420,000) ounces of gold in 2022

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: as part of Government‚Äôs policy to indigenize the mining sector, we will engage with Newmont to give priority to Ghanaian investors who will want to acquire this mine, to ensure that our mineral resources better benefit the Ghanaian people

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: some forty-two million (42 million) trees have been planted over the last three years, under the Green Ghana Project

speaker: H. E. Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo
claims: some six hundred and ninety thousand hectares (690,000 ha) of degraded forest have been cultivated between 2017 and 2022, under the Ghana Forest Plantation Strategy
